questions.text: Haldane effect is _______

choices.text: Binding of O2 to Hb favours release of CO2
Binding of CO2 to Hb favours release of O2
HCO3- leaving RBC in exchange for Cl-

questions.solution:
Binding of O2 with hemoglobin tends to displace CO2 from the blood. This effect is called the Haldane effect. (Remember - Haldane effect occurs in lungs and causes left shift of O2-Hb dissociation curve)

Haldane Effect

  • Binding of O2 with hemoglobin tends to displace CO2 from the blood. This effect, called the Haldane effect, is important in promoting CO2 transport.
  • The Haldane effect results from the simple fact that the combination of O2 with hemoglobin in the lungs causes the hemoglobin to become a stronger acid. This displaces CO2 from the blood and into the alveoli.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with classic pill rolling resting tremor and gait disturbances. The area of the brain most likely to be involved is
questions.solution:
The given case scenario suggests a diagnosis of Parkinson’s disease (PD) and the area most likely to be involved is substantia nigra, a part of the mesencephalon (midbrain).

The hallmark features of PD are degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc), reduced striatal dopamine, and intracytoplasmic proteinaceous inclusions known as Lewy bodies (containing the protein alpha synuclein).

Related Pearl: Site of Lesion of Movement Disorders

Subthalamic Nucleus

questions.text: You administer atropine at a dose of 0.5 mg IV to a patient with symptomatic bradycardia. What would be the effect on heart rate?
questions.solution:
Atropine at average clinical doses of 0.4-0.6 mg administered parenterally results in transient bradycardia followed by tachycardia.

Parasympathetic postganglionic nerve terminals in the SA node contain presynaptic M1 receptors. These receptors normally inhibit the release of ACh. Therefore stimulation of these receptors decreases the release of ACh causing tachycardia. Inhibition of these receptors increases ACh causing bradycardia. 

Atropine initially blocks these presynaptic M1 receptors. This increases the amount of ACh released at the SA node and causes bradycardia. Then, the progressive increase in the atropine concentration blocks the postsynaptic M2 receptors on the SA node (decreasing the ACh release) decreasing the parasympathetic tone, thereby causing tachycardia.

questions.text: Identify the layer of skin (in the image given below) in which desmosomes are abundant.
questions.solution:
Desmosomes are abundant in the stratum spinosum (Option C, label D in the image) layer of the epidermis of the skin.

Desmosomes are adhesion complexes in epidermis which link adjacent keratinocytes. They appear like spines on microscopy and hence this layer is also called the prickle layer. Defects of desmosomal proteins, inherited or acquired, result in blistering disorders.

Related Pearl: Cells of the epidermis

Cells of the epidermis Origin and location Characteristic features
Keratino-cytes

Present in- All Layers of Epidermis (90-95% of all epidermal cells)

Derived from-Ectoderm

Differentiated in situ

 Rich in the intermediate filaments called keratin that provides mechanical strength to the cell. The keratinocytes in basal layer divide and generate the upper layers. 
Melano-cytes

Present in- Stratum basale

Derived from-Neural Crest

Migrate to the epidermis

 Synthesize melanin in granules called melanosomes that is transferred to keratinocytes of epidermis through elongated processes called dendrites. Each melanocyte transfers melanosomes to 36 keratinocytes. This is called as Epidermal melanin unit (36K:1M)   

Merkel   cells

Present in-Stratum basale (RETE RIDGES)

Derived from-Ectoderm/ Neural Crest

Differentiates in-situ

 Also known as Touch cells or Haascheiban cells. They are Type 1 slow adapting touch receptors.  
Langerhans cells

Present in-Stratum spinosum

Derived from- Bone Marrow

Migrate to Epidermis

 They are dendritic Antigen Presenting Cells (APCs).   Characterized by presence of rod shaped or Tennis Racket shaped granules called Birbeck granules which are seen on electron microscopy.   Immunohistochemical Markers are CD1a, CD207(Langerin) and S100.

questions.text: In a reaction, the substrate is available in a concentration that is 1000 times the Km value of the enzyme.  After 9 minutes of reaction, 1% of substrate is converted to product (12 microgram/ml). If the concentration of the enzyme is changed to 1/3 and concentration of substrate is doubled, what is the time taken to convert the substrate into the same amount of product that i.e. 12 microgram/ml?
questions.solution:
The time taken for the formation of the same amount of product is 27 minutes.

In this reaction, the substrate concentration becomes 1000 times i.e much greater than the Km value. Thus, the rate of this reaction is equal to Vmax and is thus independent of the substrate concentration i.e. it follows zero-order kinetics. Thus, doubling the substrate concentration does not change the velocity of the reaction i.e. it remains as Vmax.

No matter the substrate concentration, the rate of the reaction is directly proportional to the concentration of the enzyme. In this situation the enzyme concentration becomes 1/3rd. Thus, the velocity of the reaction (Vmax) also becomes 1/3rd. This means that the time taken for the formation of the same amount of product will become tripled i.e 9 × 3 = 27 minutes.

questions.text: How will you manage a patient who is diagnosed to have acute suppurative otitis media in the pre-suppuration stage?
questions.solution:
Management of ASOM in the pre-suppuration stage involves the usage of antibiotics and decongestants. 

Myringotomy is indicated only when there is an impending rupture of tympanic membrane.

questions.text: The factors that can cause a person to drink water due to stimulation of thirst mechanism is/are ___________.
questions.solution:
Dehydration, hemorrhage, and prandial drinking: All three can cause increased thirst resulting in water drinking.

Increased osmolality acts via osmoreceptors in the anterior hypothalamus.

The decreased plasma volume, as in hemorrhage, acts via
1. Renin-angiotensin system
2. Baroreceptors in heart and blood vessels.

The intake of liquids during a meal is known as prandial drinking. The increase is known as learned or habit response but is not understood completely.

The following factors are thought to play a role
1. Increase in plasma osmolality due to food absorption
2. Action on hypothalamus by one or more gastrointestinal hormones

questions.text: After assessing a patient with a traumatic head injury, a score of 3 was given for motor response. According to the Glasgow Coma Scale, what does the score indicate?
questions.solution:
Motor response of 3 indicates decorticate posture or abnormal flexion to pain stimulus.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury

To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A patient who is planned for cardiac surgery requires central venous pressure (CVP) monitoring. What is the preferred site for central venous cannulation?
questions.solution:
The right internal jugular vein is the most preferred vein for central venous cannulation.

Reasons for preference:   

  • Absence of valves
  • Consistent anatomic location of the internal jugular vein
  • Easily identifiable surface landmarks
  • Direct communication with the right atrium. 

Other sites for central venous cannulation:

  • Subclavian vein: greater risk of pneumothorax
  • Left internal jugular vein: greater risk of pleural effusion & chylothorax
  • Femoral vein: increased risk of thromboembolic complications, infection, and vascular injury.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man was admitted for multiple episodes of seizures following 7 months of neurocognitive decline. He also had weight loss, paranoia, and delusions. Clinical workup revealed HIV infection along with the following findings on MRI. What is the ideal timing of steroid therapy in this condition?

choices.text: Just before obtaining the sample for a biopsy
There is no specific ideal timing

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of primary CNS lymphoma (PCNSL). In this condition, glucocorticoids should be administered only after a biopsy has been obtained. This is because steroids have a cytolytic effect on lymphoma cells and hence may lead to nondiagnostic tissue.  

On CT, PCNSL is identified as a hyperdense enhancing supratentorial mass. On MRI, vivid homogeneous enhancement, as well as restricted diffusion, is seen. 

PCNSL is a type of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. The workup usually includes:

  • HIV testing
  • CSF analysis
  • MRI spine 
  • PET/CT to assess the extent of the disease
  • Bone marrow biopsy

World AIDS Vaccine Day, also known as HIV Vaccine Awareness Day, is observed annually on May 18. HIV vaccine advocates mark the day by promoting the continued urgent need for a vaccine to prevent HIV infection and AIDS.

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the given dose-response curve?

choices.text: Drug B is the most potent.
Drug B is the most efficacious.
Drug C is more efficacious than drug D.
Drug A is more potent than drug B.

questions.solution:
The more the curve is on the left in a dose-response curve (DRC), the greater is its potency. Hence, Drug B is the most potent.

Potency:

  • It is defined as the amount of drug needed to produce a given response.
  • A highly potent drug evokes a given response at low concentrations and vice-versa.
  • In the above image, the potency is Drug B> Drug A > Drug C > Drug D.

Efficacy:

  • It is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug. It reflects the capacity of the drug to activate a receptor and produce the response.
  • In the log dose-response curve, the perpendicular height represents the drug efficacy.
  • Thus, in the above image, the efficacy is Drug A = Drug C =Drug D > Drug B.
  • Drugs having a similar pharmacological effect can have different efficacies e.g furosemide and metolazone are both diuretics but furosemide has greater efficacy than metolazone.

questions.text: The device shown in the image works upon the principle of:
questions.solution:
The given image shows radiant warmers. They work under the principle of radiant heating.

Incubators work under the principle of Convective Heating.

The device is set in servo control mode and the temperature is set at 36.5 to 37-degree celsius.

questions.text: A person working in the smelting industry noticed the following changes in the nails. This finding can be seen in chronic poisoning with which of the following?
questions.solution:
The image shows transverse white lines of 1 to 2mm in breadth across the nail which is called Aldrich-Mees lines and is usually seen in chronic arsenic and thallium poisoning.

Chronic Arsenic Poisoning :

  • Source: Occurs in persons engaged in smelting or refining ore or long-term exposure to arsenic compounds

Manifestations of chronic arsenic poisoning: 

System involved Symptoms
Skin Melanosis, Bowen’s disease facial edema, hyperkeratosis, cutaneous cancer, raindrop hyperpigmentation 
Nails Aldrich Mees Line: Transverse white lines in the fingernails 
Neurologic Polyneuritis, anesthesias, paraesthesia,
encephalopathy. 
GI tract Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia, weight loss
Liver Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis
Haematologic Bone marrow hypoplasia, anemia, leukopenia, basophilic stippling, and karyorrhexis
Cardiovascular Blackfoot disease due to platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries

Diagnosis: Urinary level of > 100 mg/ 24 hours suggestive of arsenic toxicity. Blood levels and hair levels are not reliable.

Laboratory tests to detect arsenic poisoning are:

  • Marsh’s test
  • Reinsch test
  • Atomic absorption spectroscopy

Management:

  • Hemodialysis is the treatment of choice for massive arsenic poisoning.
  • Chelation with BAL(British Anti Lewisite). Penicillamine or DMSA can be used instead of BAL.
  • Gastric lavage with warm water and milk

Other options:

  • Lead poisoning is characterized by a blue line on the gums called the Burtonian line. It can also be seen in mercury poisoning.
  • Mercury poisoning is characterized by mercurial tremors or Hatters shake.

Related Pearl: Arsenic poisoning

Summary of Arsenic poisoning

Source of exposure: Arsenic-containing pesticides, natural sources - drinking water and soil

Route of absorption: GI tract

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

Characteristic clinical findings are as follows: Mnemonic-ARSENIC

A- Aldrich mees lines

R- raindrop pigmentation, rash, red velvety mucosa

S- subendocardial haemorrhage

E- Excessive pigmentation- Blackfoot disease

N- Neuritis

I- Iron oxide + BAL –treatment

C- Cholera like illness

Diagnosis: 24-hour urine arsenic

Treatment: BAL; succimer(DMSA)

Clinicopathological findings in acute and chronic arsenic poisoning:

questions.text: An infant is brought with a history of vomiting and poor feeding. A musty odor is noted in the baby. Guthrie test was done and it was found to be positive. All are true regarding this disease except

choices.text: White patch of hair due to tryptophan deficiency

questions.solution:
The given scenario of an infant with a history of vomiting and poor feeding with a musty odour is suggestive of phenylketonuria (PKU). Tryptophan deficiency is not a feature of this disorder. The deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase causes PKU. 

Characteristic clinical findings in Phenylketonuria:

  • Mental retardation
  • Failure to walk or talk
  • Seizures
  • Hyperactivity
  • Tremor
  • Microcephaly
  • Failure to grow
  • Deficiency of pigmentation (fair hair, light skin color, and blue eyes)

The Guthrie bacterial inhibition test is a screening test for phenylketonuria. This test uses a phenylalanine requiring strain of Bacillus subtilis. The ferric chloride test is also used as a screening test for PKU. Tandem mass spectrometry is the gold standard investigation.

Related Pearl: Phenylketonuria

  1. BH4 - tetrahydrobiopterin (or sapropterin, a synthetic form of BH4)

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy who collapsed while playing basketball was brought to the emergency room and was resuscitated. On evaluation, he was found to have sustained ventricular tachycardia secondary to arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy. Which syndrome is associated with this?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient suffered from sustained ventricular tachycardia secondary to arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC). ARVC is associated with Naxos syndrome.

ARVC is autosomal dominant cardiomyopathy characterized by fibrofatty replacement in the myocardium of the ventricles. It most commonly affects the right ventricle. It is due to mutations in the gene encoding desmosome-associated protein plakophilin 2. This leads to defective cell-adhesion proteins in the desmosomes that link adjacent cardiac myocytes.

As shown in the image below, Naxos syndrome is characterized by woolly hair and palmoplantar hyperkeratosis.

Morphology shows severe thinning of the right ventricular wall due to loss of myocytes, accompanied by extensive fatty infiltration and fibrosis.

The image given below is a gross photograph of the heart showing dilated right ventricle and near transmural replacement of its free wall with fat and fibrosis.

Carvajal syndrome is a variant of Naxos disease but is associated with dilated cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
The image shows Babcock’s forceps.

In Babcock’s forceps, the distal part of the distal blade is curved with a triangular fenestra which allows soft tissues to bulge out. The tip is non-traumatic with transverse serrations. It has a lock in the proximal part.

It is used to hold tubular structures such as parts of the bowel, fallopian tube, appendix, ureter, etc.

Option A: Allis tissue forceps have distal blades, not opposing each other. The tip has got teeth in each blade that are opposing. There is a lock in the proximal part.

It is used to hold skin flaps, fascia, aponeurosis, and the bladder wall.

Option C: Lane’s tissue holding forceps have got stout and thick distal blades with oval fenestrae. It has an opposing tooth on the tip and a lock in the proximal part.

It is used to hold bulky and tough structures and lymph nodes.

Option D: Kocher’s hemostatic forceps - It is identified by the opposing tooth on the tip and serrations in the distal blades.

It is used to hold pedicles, tough structures, and cut ends of muscles. It is also used to hold ribs during rib dissection, gauze for blunt dissection, and resected bowel.

questions.text: Identify the structure passing through the foramen marked.
questions.solution:
The marked foramen is the superior orbital fissure and the abducens nerve passes through it.

The abducens nerve is the 6th cranial nerve and arises from the brainstem at the pontomedullary junction. It runs through the Dorello's canal which is present at the medial most end of the petrous ridge and then enters the cavernous sinus where it lies lateral to the internal carotid artery. It enters the orbit through the superior orbital fissure within the common tendinous ring and supplies the lateral rectus.

 

Other options:

Spinal accessory nerve passes through the foramen magnum along with the medulla oblongata and the verterbral arteries

Ophthalmic artery passes through the optic canal along with the optic nerve.

Middle meningeal artery and vein pass through the foramen spinosum along with the meningeal branch of mandibular nerve.

Related Pearl: Superior orbital fissure

Structures passing through the Superior orbital fissure

Above the common tendinous ring: LFT (Superolateral compartment)

  • Lacrimal nerve
  • Frontal nerve
  • Trochlear nerve
  • Superior opthalmic vein

Within the common tendinous ring: BAN (Intermediate compartment)

  • Both divisions of oculomotor nerve
  • Abducens nerve
  • Nasociliary nerve

Below the common tendinous ring (Inferomedial compartment)

  • Inferior ophthalmic vein

questions.text: Which of the following is not a differential diagnosis for a patient with suspected Ménière’s disease?
questions.solution:
CSOM is a middle ear disease with symptoms of ear discharge and is not a differential for Ménière’s.

Ménière’s is a cochlear pathology with symptoms of vertigo, hearing loss & tinnitus.

Differentials of Ménière’s disease:

  • Vestibular neuronitis
  • BPPV
  • Cervical spondylosis
  • Acoustic tumours
  • Vertebrobasilar insufficiency
  • Labyrinthitis
  • Perilymph fistula
  • Migraine induced vertigo

questions.text: A patient who had undergone a retro-oesophagal goitre resection was found to have partial ptosis and loss of hemifacial sweating. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Horner's syndrome. 

The cervical sympathetic trunk is at risk of injury in invasive thyroid cancers and retro-esophageal goitres and may result in Horner's syndrome. 

Related Pearl: Horner's syndrome

Horner's Syndrome:

Horner's syndrome occurring due to occulo-sympathetic paresis is characterized by the classic triad of:

  • Mild ptosis (due to paralysis of Muller's muscle).
  • Miosis (due to paralysis of dilator pupillae).
  • Reduced ipsilateral sweating (anhydrosis).

Other features include:

  • Mild enophthalmos,
  • Loss of cilio-spinal reflex,
  • Heterochromia, i.e., the ipsilateral iris is lighter in colour,
  • Pupil is slow to dilate, and there occurs slight elevation of lower eyelid.

Cocaine test (2% to 4%): Small pupils fail to dilate in Horner's syndrome.

In congenital Horner's syndrome, the additional features seen are heterochromia iridis and unilateral straight hair.

questions.text: A 6-month-old child has a history of recurrent skin and respiratory tract infections. Investigations are carried out and a disorder of phagocytosis is suspected. Which of the following will not be a differential diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
DiGeorge syndrome is not a disorder of phagocytosis.

It is due to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches. Cell-mediated immunity is defective due to decreased T-cells. Affected individuals also have depressed graft rejection, hypocalcemia, and cardiac defects. 

Disorders of phagocytosis:

  • Leukocyte adhesion deficiency
  • Chediak–Higashi syndrome
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia

Other options: 

Option B: Leukocyte adhesion deficiency leads to defective neutrophil migration to sites of infection, peripheral neutrophilia, and recurrent infections without pus.

Option C: Chediak–Higashi syndrome is an autosomal-recessive disorder due to defects in lysosomal transport protein (LYST), leading to defective microtubule polymerization and defective phagolysosome formation. There is neutropenia and recurrent infections. 

Option D: Chronic granulomatous disease is due to a defect in NADPH oxidase resulting in the absence of respiratory burst. It presents with recurrent infections with catalase-positive microbes.

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

 

Related Pearl: Clinical features of DiGeorge syndrome- Mnemonic

DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder caused by the deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22 (22q11) leading to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. (Thymus and parathyroid glands)

The clinical features can be remembered with the mnemonic – CATCH

  • C – Cardiac defects
  • A – Abnormal facies
  • T – Thymic aplasia
  • C – Cleft palate
  • H – Hypocalcemia

The image below shows the abnormal facies in DiGeorge syndrome.

questions.text: A radiologist observes the following finding on a patient's  X-ray. Which condition is it seen in?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows inferior rib notching. It is seen in coarctation of aorta.

The most common location of the coarctation is just beyond the origin of the left subclavian artery. The following radiograph findings are seen in this condition:

  • Inferior rib notching (Roesler sign):
    • It occurs due to erosion of inferior margins of ribs by dilated intercostal collateral vessels that are formed to bypass the coarctation 
    • It is a late feature and is unusual in patients < 5 years of age
    • Ribs 4-8 are commonly notched and ribs 1-2 are usually spared
  • Figure of 3 or reverse 3 sign refers to an abnormality in the contour of the aorta, as shown below.

Causes for inferior rib notching (Roesler sign) are:

  • Unilateral:
    • Subclavian artery occlusion.
    • Coarctation of aorta involving left subclavian or anomalous right subclavian artery
  • Bilateral:
    • Coarctation of aorta, occlusion, aortitis
    • Takayasu’s disease and atheroma of subclavian artery
    • Pulmonary oligemia (ToF, pulmonary atresia, stenosis)
    • SVC or IVC obstruction
    • AV malformation
    • Neurofibromatosis type 1

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought to the hospital with a history of loose stools. No history of fever or blood in stools. The mother says he is irritable and eagerly drinks water if given. On examination, eyes are sunken and in the skin pinch test, the skin retracted within two seconds but not immediately. What treatment is advised for the child?

choices.text: Give oral fluids and zinc supplementation only and ask mother to come back if danger sign develops.
Give oral fluids and ask mother to continue the same and visit again the next day.
Consider severe dehydration start IV fluids, IV antibiotics, and refer to higher centre.

questions.solution:
In a child with diarrhea, thirst (eagerly drinks water), sunken eyes, restless and irritable behavior, and skin pinch showing slow retraction (<2 seconds) point towards some dehydration. Treatment includes oral rehydration therapy, zinc supplementation, and continued breastfeeding according to WHO integrated management of neonatal and childhood diseases (IMNCI) plan B.

The degree of dehydration is assessed and managed using the WHO IMNCI PLAN given below: 

 

Related Pearl: Symptoms associated with different levels of dehydration

Symptoms No or minimal dehydration Mild to moderate dehydration Severe dehydration
Loss of body weight <3% 3–9% >9%
Mental status Well; alert Fatigued or irritable Lethargic or unconscious
Thirst Drinks normally Thirsty; eager to drink Drinks poorly
Heart rate Normal Normal to increased Tachycardia
Quality of pulse Normal Normal to decreased Weak, thready or impalpable
Skin turgor test Instant recoil Recoil in <2 sec Recoil in >2 sec
Capillary refill Normal Prolonged Prolonged

Related Pearl: Treatment of dehydration based on severity

Plan A: For no dehydration or minimal dehydration. ORS is administered after each loose stool.

Age Amount 
<2 years 50–100 mL
2-10 years 100–200 mL
>10 years As much fluid as they want

Plan B: For moderate dehydration.

The amount of oral rehydration solution (ORS) to be given is 75 mL/kg body weight (wt × 75).

Plan C: Severe dehydration

Age First, give 30 mL/kg in Followed by 70 mL/kg in Total 100 mL/kg in
Infants (under 12 months) 1 hr 5 hrs  6 hrs
Older 30 min 2½ hrs  3 hrs

Note: Ringer lactate (ideal) or normal saline is used as intravenous fluids.

questions.text: An adolescent male patient presents with fatigue. His total leucocyte count is 138 x 10^9 / L with 80% blasts on the peripheral smear. Chest X-ray shows a large mediastinal mass. The bone marrow aspirate is as shown below. What would the immunophenotyping of this patient’s blasts most likely demonstrate?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and bone marrow aspirate are suggestive of  T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Thus, immunophenotyping of the blasts would demonstrate an immature T-cell phenotype (Tdt/CD34/CD7 positive).

The bone marrow aspirate shows lymphoblast with condensed nuclear chromatin, small inconspicuous nucleoli, and scanty cytoplasm lacking granules. 

ALL is usually seen in adolescent boys with thymic involvement in 50% to 70%. It has an abrupt stormy onset, within days to a few weeks of the first symptoms.

Clinical features of ALL include: 

  • Bone marrow failure - anemia, fever, infections, bleeding
  • Mass effects due to neoplastic infiltration - bone pain, generalized lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and testicular enlargement
  • CNS manifestations - headache, vomiting, and nerve palsies 
  • B-ALL - Pancytopenia due to marrow involvement
  • T-ALL - Mediastinal mass, compression of  large vessels and airways in the mediastinum, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly

Related Pearl: Immunophenotyping of Acute Lymphocytic Leukemia (ALL)

Type of ALL  Immunophenotype 
Early Pre-B ALL  TdT, DR, CD19, CD24 
Pre B ALL  TdT, DR, CD10, CD19, CD20, CD24, Cy Ig 
Common ALL  CD19+,  CD10+/CALLA+ 
Mature B  ALL  DR, CD19, CD20, CD24, Surface Ig 
Pro-T ALL   CD3, CD7 
Pre-T ALL  TdT, CD2, CD3, CD4, CD5, CD7, CD8, CD34 
Mature T ALL  CD2, CD7, Tdt

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding Staphylococci except that ___.

choices.text: A majority of infections caused by coagulase-negative staphylococci are due to Staphylococcus epidermidis
Βeta-lactamase production in staphylococci is under plasmid control.
Expression of methicillin resistance in Staphylococcus aureus increases when it is incubated at 37°C in blood agar.
Methicillin resistance in Staphylococcus aureus is independent of β-lactamase production.

questions.solution:
The optimum temperature for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) expression is 30°C, whereas the optimum temperature for the growth of S. aureus is 37°C.

Other options:

Option a: More than 75% of infections caused by coagulase-negative staphylococci (CONS) are due to Staphylococcus epidermidis.

Option b: Beta-lactamase production in staphylococci is plasmid mediated, whereas PBP 2A (mecA gene is chromosomal)

Option d: Resistance in MRSA is mediated by the mecA gene, which is chromosomally coded. It alters penicillin-binding protein (PBP) present on S. aureus cell membrane to PBP-2a, which has less affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics. Thus, methicillin resistance in S. aureus is independent of β-lactamase production.

Related Pearl: Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)

MRSA Definition: Methicillin MIC 8 μg/ml or more, Oxacillin MIC 4 μg/ml or more.

Resistance in MRSA is mediated by mecA gene which is chromosomally coded. It alters PBP (penicillin-binding protein) present on S.aureus cell wall to PBP-2a which has less affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics.

Penicillin Binding Protein:

  • Normal protein present in all bacterial cell wall.
  • Transpeptidase in nature.
  • Required for cross-linking of the peptidoglycan layer (essential for cell wall synthesis).
  • It is also the site of attachment for- beta-lactam drugs to bind & inhibit.

Types of MRSA:

  • Community-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype IV and Possess PV Toxin(Panton-Valentine Toxin), monodrug resistance,more virulent
  • Hospital-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype I, II, III, multidrug resistance,less virulent.

Detection of MRSA:

  • Antibiotic susceptibility test on Muller Hilton agar (Disk diffusion test) by using Methicillin or Oxacillin disc or cefoxitin disc.
  • PCR for detection of mecA gene.

Treatment:

  • Vancomycin is Drug Of Choice (should be used only if other drugs are resistant ).
  • Others- Teicoplanin, Linezolid, streptogramin, cipro/levofloxacin, cotrimoxazole, clindamycin, mupirocin, minocycline.
  • Newer Drugs – Daptomycin, ceftobiprole, tigecycline, oritavancin, dalbavancin, telavancin, delafloxacin.
  • Ceftobiprole and ceftaroline are 5th generation β lactams effective against MRSA.

questions.text: Which of these is not a pre-leukemic condition?
questions.solution:
Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria is not a preleukemic condition. 

It is an autoimmune hemolytic anemia due to IgG autoantibodies that bind to the P blood group antigen and cause intravascular hemolysis and hemoglobinuria. Most cases are seen in children and show recovery within a month.

Option A: Few patients with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) develop acute non-lymphocytic leukemia. This is thought to arise from the injured marrow as a secondary hematopoietic disorder.

Option B: Bone marrow aplasia preceding acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is a rare condition that usually affects children. It generally follows the recovery of normal blood counts and most commonly occurs within 6 months of the onset of aplasia.

Option C: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) occurs in 10% to 40% of individuals with myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS). It is usually accompanied by the appearance of additional cytogenetic abnormalities.

questions.text:
Which of the following are not risk factors for the development of pancreatic cancer?
  1. History of acute pancreatitis
  2. Long-standing diabetes mellitus
  3. BRCA2 mutation
  4. Female gender
  5. Cigarette smoking
questions.solution:
An history of acute pancreatitis and female gender are not risk factors for the development of pancreatic cancer.

Risk factors for pancreatic cancer:

  • Demographic factors:
    • Age (peak incidence, 65–75 years)
    • Male gender
    • Black ethnicity
  • Cigarette smoking
  • Genetic factors and medical conditions
  • Family history:
    • Two first-degree relatives with pancreas cancer
    • Germline BRCA2 mutations in some rare high-risk families
  • Hereditary pancreatitis
  • Chronic pancreatitis
  • Lynch syndrome
  • Ataxia telangiectasia
  • Peutz–Jeghers syndrome
  • Familial breast-ovarian cancer syndrome
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis 
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Obesity

questions.text: An epidemiologist determines to evaluate the strength of association between asbestos exposure and mesothelioma in a case-control study. Which of the following variables would he use for it?
questions.solution:
Odds ratio (OR), also known as cross-product ratio, is used to measure the strength of association between risk factor (asbestos exposure) and outcome (mesothelioma) in case-control studies.

A case-control study yields only odds ratio and not incidence or relative risk.

Related Pearl: Odds Ratio

  • Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between risk factor and outcome in case control studies.
  • Odds ratio can be arrived at from case control studies.
  • It is also known as cross product ratio.
  • A representation of the odds ratio (OR) is given in the picture below:

Calculation of odds ratio (OR) = (a/b)/(c/d) = ad/bc where, 

  Cancer
Exposure   Yes No
Yes a b
No c d
  • OR < 1 indicates possible protection (negative association) as the frequency of exposure is lower among cases than controls.
  • OR = 1 indicates no association of risk with exposure, or that the event is equally likely in both groups.
  • OR > 1 indicates increased risk (positive association) as the frequency of exposure is greater among cases than controls.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about mucopolysaccharidosis?

choices.text: Hunter syndrome is due to a deficiency of iduronate 2-sulphatase
Hurler syndrome is due to a deficiency of α-L-iduronidase
They are inherited as autosomal recessive traits, except Hunter syndrome
Hunter syndrome is inherited as an autosomal dominant disease

questions.solution:
All the mucopolysaccharidoses are inherited as autosomal-recessive traits except Hunter syndrome. It is inherited as an X-linked recessive disease.

The mucopolysaccharidoses (MPSs) are a group of closely related syndromes that result from genetically determined deficiencies of enzymes involved in the degradation of mucopolysaccharides (glycosaminoglycans).

Mucopolysaccharides are abundant in the ground substance of connective tissues. In the absence of enzymes involved in their degradation, they accumulate within lysosomes in various tissues and organs of the body. Two among these are:

  • Hurler syndrome - deficiency of α-L-iduronidase
  • Hunter syndrome - deficiency of iduronate 2-sulphatase

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is transmitted by the vector shown in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The vector shown in the image is a tsetse fly. It transmits African sleeping sickness (African human trypanosomiasis).

Tsetse flies belong to the genus Glossina. They have not demonstrated insecticide resistance. Methods of tsetse fly control include spraying of DDT, clearing of vegetation, destruction of wild game and genetic control.

questions.text: What is the temperature of the steam in a flash autoclave?
questions.solution:
Flash autoclaves sterilize using steam at a temperature of 134° Celsius for 3 minutes. They are widely used in operating rooms.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with facial weakness and pain for the past 2 days. The following signs are seen on examination. What is the cause?
questions.solution:
The features are suggestive of lower motor neuron (LMN) type of facial palsy.

In the image, the absence of wrinkling over the right side of the forehead and incomplete closure of the right eyelid is characteristic of LMN type of facial palsy. 

In upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion, the upper part of the face is spared due to bilateral UMN innervation. 

Features of facial nerve palsy:

Feature UMN   LMN
Side affected Contralateral Ipsilateral
Facial muscles involved Lower Both upper and lower
Forehead wrinkling Present Absent
Emotional incontinence Present Absent
Corneal reflex Normal Absent
Taste Intact Affected
Atrophy of facial muscles Absent Present

Note: Deviation of the angle of mouth should not be confused with drooping of the angle of mouth. Deviation of the angle of the mouth occurs on the normal side due to the action of unaffected facial muscles, while drooping occurs on the affected side.

questions.text: Which of the following is the main arterial supply of palatine tonsils?

choices.text: Tonsillar branch of the facial artery
Descending palatine branch of maxillary artery
Ascending palatine branch of facial artery

questions.solution:
The main arterial supply of tonsil is by the tonsillar branch of the facial artery.

Five arteries supply the tonsil:

  1. Tonsillar branch of the facial artery (the main artery)
  2. Ascending palatine branch of the facial artery
  3. Ascending pharyngeal branch of the external carotid artery
  4. Dorsal lingual branches of the lingual artery
  5. Descending palatine branches of the maxillary artery

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding replication and pathogenesis of HIV?

choices.text: The period of preintegration latency may last for hours to days
Pyroptosis is due to the enzyme caspase-1
Loss of plasma membrane integrity due to viral budding is considered an indirect mechanism in CD4 dysfunction

questions.solution:
Loss of plasma membrane integrity due to viral budding is a direct mechanism involved in the CD4+ T Cell Dysfunction and Depletion.

Preintegration latency:

It is a phase in which HIV enters a resting CD4+ T cell and in the absence of an activation signal, reverse transcription of the HIV genome occurs to a limited extent but the resulting proviral DNA fails to integrate into the host genome. This period of preintegration latency may last hours to days, and if no activation signal is delivered to the cell, the unintegrated DNA undergoes degradation and loses its capacity to initiate a productive infection.

Pyroptosis:

  • The phenomenon of pyroptosis is an inflammatory form of cell death involving the up regulation of the proinflammatory enzyme caspase-1 and release of the proinflammatory cytokine IL-1 β, and it is linked to a bystander effect of HIV replication on CD4+ T cells.
  • Apoptosis is seen in “bystander” cells such as CD8+ T cells and B cells as well as in uninfected CD4+ T cells.
  • The intensity of apoptosis correlates with the general state of activation of the immune system and not with the stage of disease or with the viral burden.

Mechanisms of CD4+ T Cell Dysfunction and Depletion in HIV infection

Direct Mechanisms Indirect Mechanisms
Loss of plasma membrane integrity due to viral budding Aberrant intracellular signalling events

Accumulation of unintegrated viral DNA

Activation of DNA-dependant protein kinase during viral integration into host genome

 Autoimmunity
Interference with intercellular RNA processing Innocent bystander killing of viral antigen-coated cells 
Intracellular gp120-CD4 autofusion events Apoptosis, pyroptosis (caspase-1 associated inflammation), autophagy
Syncytia formation

Inhibition of lymphopoiesis from reduced survival cytokines and lymphoid tissue integrity

Activation-induced cell death

Elimination of HIV-infected cells by virus-specific immune response

questions.text:
In a patient with massive haemorrhage, damage control surgery is being performed. What does this consist of?
  1. Arrest of hemorrhage
  2. Sepsis control
  3. Protection from further injury
  4. Performing immediate definitive repair
  5. Administering colloids for volume expansion
questions.solution:
Damage Control Surgery refers to performing limited surgical intervention in order to arrest hemorrhage, control sepsis, and protect from further injury.

This concept of tailoring the operation to match the patient’s physiology and staged procedures to prevent physiological exhaustion is called Damage Control Surgery.

Furthermore, definitive repairs are delayed and not until the patient is hemodynamically stable and physiologically capable of sustaining the procedure. Crystalloid and colloid infusions are limited in order to avoid dilutional coagulopathy.

The term Damage Control Surgery is borrowed from the military, which ensures the continued functioning of a damaged ship above conducting complete repairs which would prevent a rapid return to battle.

questions.text: 500mg of a drug was administered to a patient. 100mg was cleared in 1 hour. How much of the drug would be left in his body after 3 hours if the excretion of the drug follows zero-order kinetics?
questions.solution:
If the excretion of the drug follows zero-order kinetics, 200mg of drug would be left in the body after 3 hours.

In zero-order kinetics, a constant amount of drug is eliminated in unit time. 

In this question, 100 mg of the drug is eliminated in 1 hour. After 3 hours,

3 x 100 = 300 mg would be eliminated.

500-300 = 200 mg will be the remaining drug in the body. 

Related Pearl: Zero order vs First order kinetics of drugs

Zero order

First order

Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

 Constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time

Rate of elimination is independent of plasma concentration

 Rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration

Clearance is more at low concentration and less at high concentration

 Clearance remains constant 

Half-life is less at low concentration and more at high concentration

 Half-life remains constant

Very few drugs follow zero-order kinetics, e.g.(WATT Power)

  • Warfarin
  • Alcohol, Aspirin
  • Tolbutamide
  • Theophylline 
  • Phenytoin

 

 Most of the drugs follow first order kinetics

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding complications of varicose vein surgery is false?

choices.text: Injury to the lymphatic system can cause secondary lymphoedema
Saphenous nerve injury causes loss of sensation in the medial aspect of the leg
The sural nerve is in danger during stripping of the great saphenous vein

questions.solution:
The sural nerve accompanies the short saphenous vein laterally along its course and supplies cutaneous sensation to the lateral malleolar region. Thus it is more prone to injury during stripping of the short saphenous vein, not the great saphenous vein.

The saphenous nerve accompanies the great saphenous vein medially from the ankle to the level of the knee and supplies cutaneous sensation to the medial leg and ankle. Thus it is more prone to injury during stripping of the great saphenous vein.

Surgery for the varicose veins extraction may trigger injury of the lymph vessels and may lead to secondary lymphedema.

Injury and inflammation to the venous system during varicose vein surgery can cause slowing and stasis of blood flow in the lower limb, making them prone to develop deep vein thrombosis postoperatively.

questions.text: An 8 days old child presents with yellow sclera, whitish stool and turmeric colour urine on 3rd day of septicaemia on broad spectrum antibiotics , the likely diagnosis is -
questions.solution:
Feature of conjugated bilirubinemia on 3rd day accompanied by sepsis in a neonate suggests diagnosis of Galactosemia, in which there is deficiency of galactose 1 phosphate uridyl transferase.

Galactosemia:

  • Deficiency of galactose 1-phosphate uridyl transferase.
  • Autosomal recessive disorder
  • Newborn infant receives high amounts of lactose from breast milk or other formulas which consists of equal amounts of glucose and galactose. Without the transferase enzyme the infant is unable to metabolize galactose 1 phosphate,the accumlation of which results in injury to kidney,liver and brain.This injury may begin prenatally in affected fetus.
  • Patients with galactosemia are at increased risk for e.coli neonatal sepsis.
  • Treatment:
    • Non lactose containing milk substitutes should be used.
    • Elimination of galactose from diet along with adequate calcium supplementation reverses growth failure and renal and hepatic dysfunction.

questions.text: The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a ________type of joint.
questions.solution:
The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a ball and socket joint.

  • The ball part is formed by the rounded head of the talus.
  • The socket is formed by 3 structures:
    • Posterior surface of the navicular
    • Anterior articular surface of the calcaneus
    • Upper surface of the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament (spring ligament).

Related Pearl: Types of Synovial Joints

Classification of Synovial Joints
Type Articular surfaces Movement Examples
1. Plane Almost flat Minimal sliding movements Intercarpal, intermetacarpal, carpometacarpal (except first), intertarsal, intermetatarsal, tarsometatarsal, joints between articular processes of vertebrae, cricothyroid joint, cricoarytenoid joint, superior tibiofibular, interchondral joint (5-9 ribs), costovertebral, costotransverse, acromioclavicular, chondrosternal (except first) joints
2. Hinge Pulley shaped Uniaxial - flexion & extension Elbow, ankle, interphalangeal joints
3. Pivot Central pivot (peg) surrounded by osteoligamentous ring Uniaxial - rotation (supination and pronation) Superior and inferior radioulnar joints, median atlantoaxial joint
4. Condylar (bicondylar) 2 convex condyles articulate with concave or flat surfaces on the other side Biaxial - but predominantly one axis movement (flexion & extension) with limited rotation Knee joint, temporomandibular joint
5. Ellipsoid Oval convex surface fitting into an elliptical concavity Biaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction Radiocarpal (wrist), metacarpophalangeal joints
6. Saddle Each articular surface has a concave and convex region fitting the convex and concave regions of the other surface Biaxial - mainly 2 axis, flexion & extension,  abduction & adduction; very limited coupled axial rotation (conjunct rotation)  First carpometacarpal joint (of thumb), calcaneocuboid joints, incudomalleolar joint, sternoclavicular joint
7. Ball & Socket Globular head fitting into a cup-shaped socket Multiaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction, and rotation Shoulder, hip, talocalcaneonavicular, incudostapedial joint

questions.text: In which of the following conditions does edema result from decreased colloidal osmotic pressure?
questions.solution:
In nephrotic syndrome, edema occurs due to massive proteinuria that leads to a decrease in plasma colloid osmotic pressure.

The common causes of reduced plasma osmotic pressure are conditions that cause inadequate synthesis or increased loss of albumin (mainly) and other plasma proteins from circulation. These conditions include:

  • Protein-losing glomerulopathies (nephrotic syndrome)
  • Liver cirrhosis (ascites)
  • Malnutrition
  • Protein-losing gastroenteropathy

Edema can also occur due to increased hydrostatic pressure as a result of impaired venous return. This is seen in conditions like:

  • Congestive heart failure
  • Deep venous thrombosis
  • Renal artery stenosis

questions.text: You are planning to start treatment in a middle-aged man diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis. He has a history of chronic kidney disease and his current creatinine clearance is 25 mL/min. Which of the following drugs is least likely to require dose modification?
questions.solution:
Rifampicin is the least likely drug to require dose modification in renal failure patients as it is metabolized in the liver and primarily excreted in bile. 

In patients with renal failure, the half-life of isoniazid will be prolonged, but its adverse effects are not significantly increased. Hence dose modification is not usually done for isoniazid in clinical practice as a reduction in dose may render the regimen ineffective and increase the chances of resistance.

Ethambutol and streptomycin are primarily excreted unchanged through the renal system and need dose modification in renal failure.

This is a controversial question. Upon thorough review, we found that both rifampicin and isoniazid do not require dose adjustment. However, rifampicin would be the single best answer as it has a safer profile in CKD patients.

Related Pearl: Key points on the first line drugs used in the treatment of TB

Drugs Isoniazid Rifamycins Pyrazinamide Ethambutol
Mechanism of action

Bactericidal

Blocks mycolic acid synthesis.

Bactericidal (maximum)

Inhibition of RNA polymerase, leading to the inhibition of RNA synthesis.

Bactericidal

Inhibition of fatty acid synthase-I, leading to the inhibition of the cell membrane.

Bacteriostatic

Inhibition of arabinosyl transferase, leading to a reduction in arabinogalactan needed for the cell wall.
Location of Mycobacteria Intracellular +  Extracellular Intracellular +  Extracellular  Intracellular  Extracellular
Metabolism Liver  Liver (maximum)  Liver  Kidney
Unique side effects

Shoulder hand syndrome and CNS side effects.

 Orange urine, sweat, and tears. Flu-like symptoms with intermittent dosing.

The most hepatotoxic drug. It also causes hyperuricemia.

Optic neuritis and hence, not preferred in children.
Mechanism of resistance

Kat G mutation- the most severe form of resistance.

Inh a gene overexpression-  confers cross-resistance with ethionamide.

Mutation in rpoB- the gene coding for the β subunit of RNA polymerase.

 Mutation of the Pnca gene.

Mutations in the embB gene.

questions.text: A 24-year-old adult presents to the ER after a high velocity road traffic accident with tachypnea, petechial haemorrhages in the palpebral conjunctiva and lung crepitations. His femur radiograph is as below. The best treatment option is?
questions.solution:
External fixation is the best treatment option in the given case.

The radiograph shows a femur shaft fracture, and with the additional information in the question, the diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome should be borne in mind. In keeping with the principles of damage control orthopedics, the fracture is initially stabilized by external fixation to prevent further progression of fat embolism. Definitive treatment plans are considered later.

Damage control Orthopedics (DCO):

  • DCO identifies patients that are at risk for SIRS and organ dysfunction and provides a limited surgical intervention in order to control both hemorrhage and contamination.
  • Early temporary fixation of fractures is done with external fixation. Delayed definitive fracture fixation is done once the condition of the patient is optimal.

Intramedullary nailing is not done as it would increase the intramedullary pressure and cause more fat embolism.

Interesting fact: The term damage control was initially described by the US Navy as the capacity of the ship to absorb damage and maintain mission integrity.

questions.text: The IVP imaging of a 30-year-old woman is given below. What is it diagnostic of?
questions.solution:
The given intravenous pyelogram is characteristic for medullary sponge kidney. It shows ectatic distal collecting ducts containing microcalcifications, which is called bouquet of flowers appearance. Dilated contrast-filled tubules within the renal medulla are also seen, which is known as paintbrush appearance. 

This is a developmental defect affecting the formation of collecting tubules and results in cystic dilatation of the medullary and papillary portions of collecting ducts.

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text: The following image shows which type of GI motility?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the migrating motor complex.

The image shows 3 phases: 

  • Phase I - quiescent period
  • Phase II - period of irregular electrical & mechanical activity
  • Phase III - ends with bursts of regular activity

This occurs during the inter-digestive period at intervals of about 100 min and passes in the aboral direction at the rate of 5 cm/min. Its main function is to clear intestinal contents and prepare for the next meal.

Option A: Peristalsis is a propulsive movement, which consists of a segment of contraction behind and relaxation in front.

Option B: Segmentation and mixing help in mixing intestinal contents with digestive juices and provides time for digestion and absorption.  

It consists of a segment of bowel contracting at both ends, and then a second contraction occurs in the center of the segment to force the chyme both backward and forward.

Option D: Basal Electrical Rhythm is fluctuation in the resting membrane potential of smooth muscle cells of the intestine as shown below.

questions.text: In a sample of DNA if adenine is 23%, what will be the amount of guanine?
questions.solution:
In a sample of DNA, if adenine is 23%, guanine will be 27%.

This is based on Chargaff’s rule which states that the number of purines is equal to the number of pyrimidines.

Purines include adenine and guanine. Pyrimidines include thymine and cytosine. The two strands of DNA are complementary to each other. So, the adenine of one strand will pair with thymine of the opposite strand, while guanine will pair with cytosine.

  • Step 1:

No of adenine = No of thymine

So adenine + thymine = 46%

Guanine + cytosine = 54%

  • Step 2:

No of guanine = No of cytosine

So, amount of guanine = 54/2 = 27%

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of glare and discomfort of the eyes. Findings seen on slit-lamp examination are given below. He suffers from lupus erythematosus, for which he is being treated with chloroquine. Which of the following findings would you expect to see on a fundoscopy?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the slit lamp findings of cornea verticillata point to toxicity caused due to chloroquine. The fundoscopy in this patient is most likely to reveal bull’s eye maculopathy.

Prolonged administration of chloroquine leads to bull’s eye maculopathy.  

The image below shows bull’s eye maculopathy:

 

Causes of Bull’s eye maculopathy: 

  • Chloroquine maculopathy
  • Advanced Stargardt disease
  • Cone and cone-rod dystrophy
  • Fenestrated sheen macular dystrophy
  • Benign concentric annular macular dystrophy
  • Clofazimine retinopathy.

Cornea Verticillata is a condition where a whorl-like opacity is seen in the corneal epithelium seen on treatment with medica­tion such as chloroquine, amiodarone, phenothiazines, and indomethacin. It is also seen in Fabry disease.

Hypotonic maculopathy is the maculopathy occurring because of decreased intraocular pressure (less than 6 mmHg). It usually occurs due to excessive drainage after glaucoma filtration surgery.

questions.text: An adrenal incidentaloma was detected in a patient who underwent evaluation for renal calculi. Which of the following statements are true regarding this condition?

choices.text: The majority of these adrenal masses are functional tumours
The likelihood of the adrenal mass being an adrenocortical carcinoma is independent of the size of the mass
The only indication for biopsy of this adrenal mass is to confirm adrenal gland metastasis

questions.solution:
The only indication for an adrenal gland biopsy is to confirm adrenal gland metastasis.

An adrenal incidentaloma is defined as a clinically unapparent adrenal lesion that is incidentally detected on imaging performed for indications other than evaluation for adrenal disease. The majority of these lesions are non-functional tumours i.e. benign. The likelihood of an adrenal mass being an adrenocortical carcinoma increases with the size of the mass (25% chance if size >4 cm).

Incidentalomas are evaluated to classify them as functional and non-functional. Non-functional incidentalomas <4cm are managed conservatively with MRI surveillance every 3-6 months. If >4cm, laparoscopic adrenalectomy is done.

Note: An adrenal mass should never be biopsied until a pheochromocytoma has been biochemically excluded.

questions.text: Find the correct match regarding collagen proteins in the human body.

choices.text: Type I – Forms sheets or meshwork
Type III – Anchoring or linking role

questions.solution:
Type II collagen proteins are involved in forming fibrils.

Regarding collagen proteins in the human body,

  • Types I, II, III, V and XI, form fibrils.
  • Types IV, VIII and X form sheets or meshwork.
  • Types VI, VII, IX, XII, XIV and XVIII have an anchoring or linking role.
  • Types XIII and XVII are transmembrane proteins.

However, biochemically all the collagens have a number of features in common. They are triple helical polypeptides containing high levels of hydroxyproline.

questions.text: A type 2 diabetic patient who was recently started on treatment complains of frequent urination, fever, and burning micturition. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of a urinary tract infection (UTI). This adverse effect occurs as a result of dapagliflozin use.

The group of sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 or SGLT-2 inhibitors includes drugs like dapagliflozin and canagliflozin. These drugs prevent glucose reabsorption in the renal tubules and cause loss of sodium and glucose. 

  • UTI - due to glucosuria
  • Dehydration - due to natriuresis and volume loss
  • Euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis - low blood glucose levels due to glucosuria can reduce insulin release

SGLT-2 inhibitors must be temporarily discontinued for 3-4 days before any scheduled surgery to avoid potential risk for diabetic ketoacidosis.

The FDA recently approved dapagliflozin oral tablets to reduce the risk of renal and cardiac failure in adults with chronic kidney disease who are at risk of disease progression.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl has the pallor of extremities followed by pain and cyanosis on exposure to cold. Which of the following diseases is she likely to develop in the later stages of life?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario suggests that the patient has Raynaud phenomenon, which is associated with the risk of developing scleroderma in later stages of life.

Raynaud phenomenon is manifested as episodic vasoconstriction of the arteries and arterioles of the extremities, causing pallor of extremities followed by pain and cyanosis. It is seen in virtually all patients with systemic sclerosis or scleroderma and precedes other symptoms in 70% of cases.

The image shows features of Raynaud's phenomenon.

Systemic sclerosis is characterized by progressive fibrosis involving the skin, gastrointestinal tract, and other tissues. Fibrosis may be the result of the activation of fibroblasts by cytokines produced by T cells.

Focal, and sometimes diffuse, subcutaneous calcifications may develop, especially in patients with CREST syndrome. The most ominous manifestation is malignant hypertension.

questions.text: An outbreak of viral hepatitis A was reported from a town between June and September of a particular year. The peak of the outbreak occurred in July. What is this an example of?
questions.solution:
This outbreak of viral hepatitis A is an example of a common source, multiple exposure type of epidemic.

The incubation period of hepatitis A is approximately 28 days (range 15 to 50 days). In this scenario, the cases of viral hepatitis A have occurred over a period from June to September (120 days) which is more than one incubation period of the disease. This is suggestive of multiple exposures from a common source.

If the period of the outbreak falls within one incubation period, then the type of epidemic is common source ,single exposure or point source epidemic.

Difference between single exposure and multiple exposure epidemics:

  Common source, single exposure epidemic Common source, multiple exposure epidemic
Nature of exposure Single, brief exposure Multiple, continuous or intermittent exposures for a prolonged time
Nature of epidemic Explosive with clustering of cases within a short interval of time Less chance of clustering of cases within short interval of time
Duration of epidemic Falls <1 incubation period of a particular disease Extends >1 incubation period of a particular disease
Example An epidemic of food poisoning  Outbreak of cholera

Propagated epidemic results from person to person transmission of the infectious agent over a prolonged duration of time. For e.g. Polio epidemic, COVID-19.

Note: Hepatitis A epidemic is generally an example of a propagated epidemic. However, it does not always follow this pattern. In the given scenario, since the outbreak lasts for a short duration of 3 months (about 3 incubation periods for hepatitis A), it is considered to be a point source, multiple exposure outbreak.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions is associated with ADAMTS13 deficiency?
questions.solution:
ADAMTS13 deficiency is associated with thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP).

ADAMTS13 is also called vWF metalloprotease which degrades very high-molecular-weight multimers of von Willebrand factor (vWF). Its deficiency causes accumulation of these multimers in the plasma and promotes platelet activation and aggregation.

TTP is a part of a spectrum of clinical syndromes called thrombotic microangiopathy. They are caused by insults that lead to excessive activation of platelets, which deposit as thrombi in small blood vessels.

Features of TTP include:

  • Fever
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia
  • Transient neurologic deficits
  • Renal failure

Related Pearl: Differences between TTP and HUS

questions.text: A patient was brought into the emergency room by his friend with features of acute intoxication that are attributed to nicotine alkaloids derived from the plant shown below. What category of poisons does this fall under?
questions.solution:
Nicotine is a plant alkaloid derived from the Nicotiana tabacum plant shown in the image above. It is a cardiac poison.

All components of this plant are poisonous except its ripe seeds. Leaves of this plant contain toxic alkaloids, like nicotine, anabasine, nornicotine and lobeline. It is a cardiac poison that initially stimulates autonomic ganglia to produce symptoms of acute intoxication (tachycardia, bradycardia,  hypotension, tachypnea, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and headache). These symptoms later subside to give way to respiratory depression and collapse.

Other cardiac poisons are:

Digoxin is a cardiac poison derived from the roots, leaves, and seeds of the plant Digitalis purpurea (shown below). It acts to prolong the diastolic period of the cardiac muscle. Bradycardia, extrasystoles, ventricular tachycardia, and fibrillation are manifestations of toxicity. Ocular symptoms such as photopsia (colour changes), scotoma, and transient amblyopia can also be seen.

Aconite is a cardiac poison derived mainly from the root and root tubers of the plant Aconite napellus (shown below). Symptoms of intoxication are due to action on the voltage-gated sodium channels on the cell membrane of nerves, and skeletal and smooth muscles. Symptoms consist of intestinal (nausea, vomiting, perioral tingling and numbness, abdominal pain and diarrhoea), cardiovascular (chest pain, palpitations, hypotension, bradycardia), neurological (vertigo and restlessness), ocular (hippus - pupils alternately contract and dilate, diplopia and impaired vision.)

Aconite is an ideal homicidal poison - 

  • Cheap and easily available 
  • Lethal dose is small and short fatal period
  • Taste can be masked by giving it with betel leaves 
  • Cannot be detected by chemical analysis.
  • Also used as an abortifacient, cattle and arrow poison.

Thevetin is a cardiac poison derived from the plant Cerebra Thevetia (yellow oleander). All parts of the plant are poisonous. Symptoms of intoxication are characterized by vomiting, diarrhoea, headache, dizziness, mydriasis, and loss of muscular power. Cardiovascular signs include a weak and irregular pulse rate with hypotension. Possible complications are heart block and cardiorespiratory failure. 

Quinine - Derived from the bark of the Cinchona plant and it causes cinchonism due to repeated therapeutic exposures its symptoms are tinnitus, vertigo, deafness, scotoma, hypoglycemia and arrhythmias. 

Other options:

Option A: Spinal poisons- Strychnine (Strychnus nux vomica), gelsemium. Strychnine acts at the ventral horn by blocking the postganglionic glycine receptor sites in the spinal cord and brainstem. The blockade of these receptors by strychnine results in unopposed muscle contraction, resulting in the classical clinical features such as tonic-clonic seizures, opisthotonus (body arched in hyperextension) and risus sardonicus.

Option B: Deliriants -  Datura, belladonna, hyoscyamus, cannabis, cocaine.

Option C: Asphyxiants -  A toxic or non-toxic gas that causes respiratory embarrassment and leads to unconsciousness or death by asphyxiation. 

Asphyxiants can be classified into:

Asphyxiant Description Examples
Simple Asphyxiants Inert gases that displace oxygen
  • Noble gases
  • Carbon dioxide
  • Hydrocarbons
Chemical Asphyxiants Reduce the body's ability to absorb, transport or utilize oxygen
  • Carbon monoxide
  • Cyanide
  • Hydrogen sulphide
Irritant Asphyxiants Damage the respiratory tract
  • Ammonia
  • Formaldehyde
  • Methyl isocyanate
Systemic Asphyxiants Produce significant systemic toxicity by specialized mechanisms
  • Carbon monoxide
  • Cyanide

Blackouts, nystagmus and slurring of speech

Diarrhea, yawning, mydriasis, lacrimation, piloerection, cold turkey phenomenon
Euphoria, depressed mental status, miosis, respiratory depression, constipation.

Shows a biphasic pattern. 
Early stimulatory symptoms of vomiting, hypertension and tachycardia. Later depressive symptoms of hypotension and bradycardia.
Cannabis

Increased appetite, euphoria, conjunctival injection, dry mouth, panic, synesthesia, impaired time perception, amotivational syndrome, run amok and flashbacks.
Amphetamine

Acute: Sympathetic overactivity, paranoid hallucinatory syndrome, violent behavior, psychosis and diaphoresis.
Chronic: Runs & crashes, choreiform movements, tooth decay. Can resemble schizophrenia.

Related Pearl: Plant poisons

Ricinus communis : Seed is poisonous

Related Pearl: Toxic manifestations of Datura

  • Mnemonic: "hot as a hare, blind as a bat, dry as a bone, red as a beet, and mad as a hatter"
  • Also, remember the D's of Datura
    • Dry hot skin (Temp rises upto 42 C, a scarlet rash may also be appreciated).
    • Dilatation of pupils along with loss of accommodation
    • Diplopia
    • Dryness of the mouth and throat, unquenchable thirst
    • Dysphagia
    • Dilatation of cutaneous blood vessels
    • Dysarthria (Difficulty in talking)
    • Drunken gait
    • Delirium

questions.text: The blood smear slides (A) and (B) prepared from a patient suspected with malaria are shown below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding these tests?

choices.text: Slide (A) is used for estimating the parasite concentration
Slide (A) has been air dried for 10 minutes
Slide (B) cannot be used for detecting the species of the parasite
Jaswant Singh Bhattacharya stain is used for both

questions.solution:
Slide (A) is a thin blood smear and slide (B) is a thick blood smear. Thin blood smears (slide A) are not used for estimating parasite concentration. They are used to detect the species of parasite.

Microscopy is the best method for the diagnosis of malaria due to its high sensitivity and specificity. Jaswant Singh Battacharya (JSB) stain is used for staining both thick and thin smears.

Thick smear is used to detect infection and estimate parasite concentration. The correct thickness is the thickness through which a newsprint is barely visible. It is prepared by slow-drying for 30 minutes, which leads to hemolysis and distortion of the plasmodia morphology. Hence, species cannot be detected.

Thin smear is used to identify the particular infecting species of Plasmodium. It is prepared by air drying for 10 minutes and fixed in methanol. Thus, the plasmodia morphology is not distorted.

questions.text: The drug of choice for insomnia in blind people is
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for insomnia in blind people is tasimelteon.

Option A - Latanoprostene is used in primary open-angle glaucoma.

Option B - Zerviate is a cetirizine ophthalmic solution used in allergic conjunctivitis.

Option D - Ramelteon is a synthetic tricyclic analog of melatonin used in sleep onset difficulty insomnia.

questions.text: At which of the following points is the recurrent laryngeal nerve at the highest risk for injury during thyroid surgery?

choices.text: At the level of Berry's ligament as it enters the larynx
In the tracheoesophageal groove as it forms one side of the Beahrs triangle
Under the tubercle of Zuckerkandl on the posterolateral portion of the gland
As the nerve loops around the aorta

questions.solution:
The point at which the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) is at the highest risk for injury during thyroid surgery is at its entry point into the larynx. This point is at the cricothyroid joint, at the level of Berry's ligament.

The recurrent laryngeal nerve is a branch of the vagus nerve. On the left, it recurs over the arch of aorta, and on the right over the subclavian artery.

Beahrs' triangle or recurrent laryngeal nerve triangle is formed by:

  • Common carotid artery
  • Inferior thyroid arteries
  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve

Note: On the left side, the nerve has more distance in which to reach the transesophageal groove. Hence it runs in a medial plane. On the right, there is less distance and the nerve runs more obliquely to reach the groove.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-metabolites act as an antifungal agent?
questions.solution:
Flucytosine is an anti-metabolite that acts as an antifungal agent.

Fungal cytosine deaminase converts flucytosine to 5-fluorouracil, which is an anticancer drug. 5-fluorouracil is further converted into metabolites that inhibit thymidylate synthase, an enzyme that is necessary for DNA synthesis. Thus fungal DNA synthesis is inhibited. Mammalian cells are spared as it lacks cytosine deaminase enzyme.

Flucytosine has clinically useful activity (3C) against

  • Cryptococcus
  • Candida albicans
  • Chromoblastomycosis

The current pharmacological utility of flucytosine is in the treatment of HIV-associated cryptococcal meningitis (in combination with amphotericin B) and in chromoblastomycosis (in combination with itraconazole).

Other options:

Option A - Methotrexate is an antimetabolite that inhibits the enzymes dihydrofolate reductase and thymidylate synthase. It impairs de novo synthesis of purine nucleotides. It is used in the management of breast, head & neck, bladder cancers as well as lymphomas (primary central nervous system lymphoma, non-Hodgkin's).

Option B - Cladribine is an antimetabolite (purine nucleoside analog) that inhibits the enzyme ribonucleotide reductase (impaired formation of deoxyribonucleotides) and integrates cladribine triphosphate into DNA (renders DNA non-functional). It is used to treat hairy cell leukemia, CLL, and lymphoma.

Option C - Clofarabine is an antimetabolite (purine nucleoside analog) with action similar to that of cladribine. It is used in the treatment of pediatric ALL that is resistant to two prior chemotherapeutic treatments. It is also used in the treatment of pediatric and adult acute myeloid leukemias, and in myelodysplasia.
