questions.text: Which of the following has least activity on beta 2 receptors?
questions.solution:
Norepinephrine has feeble activity on beta 2 receptors.

Option A - Methylation of an amino group of norepinephrine yields epinephrine that has significant beta 2 activity.

Option C - Isoproterenol: non-selective (beta 1+beta2) beta agonist.

Option D - Terbutaline: selective beta 2 agonists.

questions.text: The image shows recent X Ray images set of a person. Based on the age conclusion you draw from it, which of the following medicolegal significance has been wrongly concluded?

choices.text: This person would not be considered major if he was under court guardianship
If the person were a boy he wouldn’t be old enough to enter into a  marriage
If the person were a female and had been imported into India recently, illicit intercourse would be punishable by Sec 366 B

questions.solution:
The approximate age of this person based on the  X-Ray is at least 21 years.

Bone/ joint Maximum age at fusion Interpretation of given X-ray
Elbow joint centres 16 years Fused, >16 years
Wrist joint centres 19 years Fused, > 19 years
Hip bone centres 22 years Fused, > 21 years

Since all the above centres are fused in this person, the age must be more than 21 years.

  1. Legal age for marriage for boys
  2. Illicit intercourse by a female imported into India is punishable under Sec 366 B IPC if the female is less than 21 years of age 
  3. A person under the guardianship of the Court would be considered a major after the age of 21 years.

Hence, all of the options are wrong regarding the medicolegal significance of 21 years. 

For estimation of age between 6 to 12 years take X-rays of elbow and wrist joint - 

  • 6 years - Appearance of centre for the lower end of ulna and medial epicondyle of the humerus.
  • 9 years - Appearance of olecranon
  • 9 to 11 years - Appearance of trochlea of humerus
  • 10 to 11 years - Appearance of pisiform
  • 11 years - Appearance of lateral epicondyle of humerus 

For estimation of age between 13 to 16 years take X-rays of elbow joint and pelvis.

  • 13 years - Appearance of separate centers in triradiate cartilage of acetabulum.
  • 12 to 14 years - Appearance of lesser trochanter of femur.
  • 14 years - Appearance of iliac crest and fusion of medial epicondyle of humerus. 
  • 15 years - Fusion of triradiate cartilage of acetabulum.
  • 16years - Appearance of ischial tuberosity and fusion of lower end of humerus, olecranon to ulna and upper end of radius.

Age at which fusion of bones/joints- 

  • 16 years - Elbow joint
  • 16 to 17 years - ankle joint 
  • 17 to 18 years - Hip joint
  • 18 to 19 years - Knee, shoulder and wrist joints
  • 20 to 21 years - Fusion of ileac crest, ischial tuberosity and inner end of the clavicle.

questions.text: You are examining the peripheral smear of a patient with anaemia and see the following finding. Name the finding and its pathogenesis.

choices.text: Howell Jolly body - ineffective RBC enucleation

questions.solution:
The marked structure in this peripheral smear showing figure of 8 appearance is a Cabot ring. They are RBC inclusion bodies seen in conditions due to ineffective erythropoiesis. It is considered a remnant of microtubules during cell division.

Cabot rings can be seen in the following conditions:

  • Megaloblastic anaemia
  • Post-splenectomy patients
  • Lead poisoning
  • Hemolytic anemias 

Option A: Heinz bodies are due to oxidative damage, seen in G6PD deficiency.

Option B: Basophilic stippling is due to ribosomal precipitation, seen in heavy metal poisoning, thalassemia and sickle cell disease.

Option D: Howell Jolly bodies are due to ineffective RBC enucleation, characteristic of asplenia.

questions.text: Which of the following is an immunologically privileged site?
questions.solution:
The seminiferous tubules are an immunologically privileged site.

Immunologically privileged sites can tolerate the introduction of antigens without eliciting an immune response. This allows a higher likelihood of graft survival, even without perfect HLA matching. As a result, an allograft can be placed in these sites without endangering a rejection reaction.

The unique immune tolerance in these regions is primarily due to the lack of effective lymphatic drainage, which prevents antigen presentation to the immune system, and the presence of blood-tissue barriers that restrict immune cell infiltration. Low vascularity contributes to immune privilege by minimising antigen exposure and immune cell recruitment. 

Examples of immune-privileged sites are the anterior chamber of the eye, cornea, testes, and brain. 

Note: Although part of the brain, the blood-brain barrier is absent at the area postrema, therefore it is not an immune-privileged site.

questions.text: An infant was brought to the casualty with an incessant cry, abdominal distension, and a history of passing blood-stained stools. Target sign was noted in the right hypochondrium on ultrasonography. What would you expect to see in the barium enema study?
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical scenario and the target sign observed on ultrasonography, intussusception is the likely diagnosis. A barium enema study in this condition is likely to show a coiled spring appearance, caused by the barium outlining the lumen of the intussusceptum and the surrounding intraluminal space. 

The images given below are the barium enema study showing a coiled spring appearance.

Other options:

Options B and C: Raspberry thorn appearance and rose thorn appearance on barium study are seen in Crohn's disease.

Option D: Saw tooth appearance on barium enema is seen in colonic diverticulosis.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with a history of fall 1 year back with parietal bone fracture, has now presented with a painful and growing parietal swelling. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of a child with a painful and growing parietal swelling, coupled with a history of a prior parietal bone fracture one year ago, strongly suggests the diagnosis of a growing fracture, also known as traumatic encephalocele or leptomeningeal cysts.

Skull fractures associated with a dural tear may fail to heal properly. The herniated brain, dilated ventricles, or a leptomeningeal cyst may cause an enlargement of this tear. These fractures are called growing skull fractures. They are usually seen in children < 3 years of age.

They present as a localized swelling or palpable skull defect that increases in size, most commonly seen in the parietal region. However, they may go undetected for years and present with delayed onset of neurologic symptoms (headache, seizure, or neurologic deficit). 

Other options:

Option A: The extended duration of one year makes scalp hematoma unlikely, as it usually resolves within a few months.

Option C: Subdural hygromas are characterized by fluid accumulation in the subdural space. Most patients with subdural hygromas are asymptomatic, but uncommon symptoms may include headaches, changes in mental status, nausea and vomiting, focal neurological deficits, and seizures. They don't present with scalp swelling.

Option D: Chronic abscess may show inflammatory changes like erythema, pus, sinus, and systemic features like fever.

questions.text: How is an electrical synapse different from a chemical synapse?

choices.text: No cytoplasmic continuity between presynaptic and postsynaptic membrane
Connexons are involved in electrical synapse
Electrical synapse has more latent period than chemical synapse

questions.solution:
In electrical synapses, the cytoplasm of adjacent cells is directly connected by gap junctions (connexons) that allow free movement of ions from the interior of one cell to the interior of the next cell.

The transmis­sion in electrical synapses is bidirectional and there is no synaptic delay. Unlike chemical synapses, electrical synapse has cytoplasmic continuity.

Note:  

Most of the synapses used for signal transmission in the central nervous system are chemical synapses.

Related Pearl: Differences between Chemical and Electrical Synapses

Property

Chemical Synapse

Electrical Synapse

Distance between pre- and post-synaptic membranes

20-40 nm

4nm

Cytoplasmic continuity between pre- and post-synaptic cells

No

Yes

Ultrastructural components

Presynaptic vesicles and active zones; post synaptic receptors

Gap junctions

Agents of transmission

Chemical transmitter

Ion current

Synaptic delay

Significant: atleast 0.3 ms, usually 1-5 ms or longer

Virtually absent

Direction of transmission

Unidirectional

Usually bidirectional

questions.text: Abrupt stoppage of which of the following drugs causes agitation, anxiety and insomnia?
questions.solution:
Abrupt stoppage of venlafaxine causes agitation, anxiety, and insomnia.

The answer has been revised from imipramine to venlafaxine. Even though both Tricyclic Antidepressants (TCAs) (imipramine) and Serotonin-Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitors (SNRIs) (venlafaxine) can cause these symptoms on abrupt stoppage, venlafaxine is the single best answer choice here as the discontinuation syndrome has been characteristically reported with venlafaxine.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with Crohn’s disease presents with red tender swellings on the lower leg as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of erythema nodosum seen in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). 

Erythema nodosum is a dermatologic manifestation of IBD. It is seen in both ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease. It manifests as tender erythematous nodules on the anterior surface of the lower legs, ankles, thighs, and arms.

Option A: Pyoderma gangrenosum is a dermatological manifestation of IBD. It begins as pustular lesions which then ulcerate with necrotic foci and exudation.

Option C: Sweet’s syndrome is acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis, seen in ulcerative colitis.

Option D: Ecthyma gangrenosum is a skin infection caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, often seen in immunocompromised patients. It presents as pustules/vesicles which progress to necrotic ulcers.

questions.text: A grand multipara had continuous, moderate vaginal bleeding immediately after delivery. What could be the most probable cause of bleeding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Uterine atony is the most common cause of postpartum haemorrhage in a grand multipara.

Uterine atony is the failure of the uterus to contract sufficiently after delivery. Contraction helps to arrest bleeding from vessels at the placental implantation site.

Types of PPH:

  1. Primary/early: Haemorrhage occurring within 24 hours of childbirth. Uterine atony is the most common cause of primary PPH.
  2. Secondary/late: Hemorrhage occurring after 24 hours and up to 12 weeks postpartum. Retained placenta is the most common cause.

The risk factors for atonic uterus include:

  1. Primiparity or grand multiparity
  2. Previous PPH
  3. Overdistended uterus as in multiple pregnancies, hydramnios, macrosomia
  4. Precipitate labour
  5. Prolonged labour
  6. Uterine malformations
  7. Uterine fibroid
  8. Induction of labour with prostaglandins or oxytocin
  9. Placental abnormalities like placenta previa, accreta, increta, percreta, or abruptio placenta
  10. Obesity
  11. Age >40 years

Note: Uterine inversion occurs rarely and causes secondary PPH.

questions.text: The given image is a transverse section of the mid-thigh. The architecture of the muscle highlighted in the image can be best described as
questions.solution:
The muscle marked in the given image is Adductor magnus.
It is a massive triangular muscle which is considered as partially cruciate and partially spiral. It is because it contains two or more planes of fibres arranged in differing directions. Other examples of such types of muscles are Sternocleidomastoid and Masseter.

Adductor magnus is a composite muscle which means it is doubly innervated by the obturator nerve and by the tibial division of the sciatic nerve.

Related Pearl: Classification of muscles according to their shape/direction of muscle fibers

Muscles with parallel fasciculi

Muscles with oblique fasciculi

Muscles with spiral or twisted fasciculi

 

Quadrilateral: Thyrohyoid

Triangular: Temporalis, Adductor longus, 

Spiral: Pectoralis major, Latissimus dorsi, Supinator and Trapezius

Strap like: Sartorius, Sternohyoid

Unipennate: Extensor digitorum longus, Flexor pollicis longus, Peroneus tertius, Palmar interossei

Partially cruciate and partially spiral: Masseter, Adductor magnus, Sternoclediomastoid 

Strap like with tendinous intersections: Rectus abdominis

Bipennate: Rectus femoris, Flexor hallucis longus, Peroneus longus, Dorsal interossei

 

Fusiform: Biceps brachii, digastric

Multipennate: Deltoid, Subscapularis

  

 

Circumpennate: Tibialis anterior

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the position of the hand shown in the picture is wrong?

choices.text: There is 70 degree flexion at metacarpophalangeal joint
The position shown above is the James position
There is 60 to 70 degree extension at the proximal interphalangeal joint
This position can reduce the risk of contractures

questions.solution:
"There is a 60° to 70° extension at the proximal interphalangeal joint" is the wrong statement among the given options.

The given image shows flexion of metacarpophalangeal joints at 70° and the interphalangeal joints are in minor degrees of flexion.

The position of the hand shown in the picture above is called as James position, also known as the intrinsic plus position of the hand. This is the functional position of the hand and is the position of safe immobilization especially in crush injuries of the hand and has the least risk for contractures. There is flexion of metacarpal phalangeal joints at 70 degrees and the interphalangeal joints are usually placed in minor degrees of flexion or extension. If possible, the fingertips are usually left exposed to observe the circulation.

questions.text: Granular deposits are seen in rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis type______.
questions.solution:
Granular deposits are seen in rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) type II.

Related Pearl: Types of Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis

Type I (Anti-GBM Antibody)

Renal limited

Goodpasture syndrome

Immunofluorescence: 

Linear GBM deposits of IgG and C3

Type II (Immune Complex)

Idiopathic

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis
Crescentic glomerulonephritis

Lupus nephritis

Henoch–Schönlein purpura

IgA nephropathy

Others: Cryoglobulinemia, Bacterial endocarditis, sepsis, acute pancreatitis/advanced liver disease

Immunofluorescence: Granular pattern of staining

Type III (Pauci-Immune)

ANCA-associated

Idiopathic

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly Wegener granulomatosis)

Microscopic polyangiitis
Immunofluorescence: No immunoglobulin or complement deposits

 

Image: Crescentic glomerulonephritis (PAS stain) with the crescent-shaped mass of proliferating parietal epithelial cells and leukocytes internal to Bowman capsule.

questions.text: A patient presents with endophthalmitis 5 days after cataract surgery. All of the following treatments can be used, except _____.
questions.solution:
Intravenous steroids are not used for the treatment of endophthalmitis.

Endophthalmitis is defined as an intraocular inflammation that predominantly affects the inner spaces of the eye and their contents, i.e. the vitreous and/or the anterior chamber. The cardinal features of endophthalmitis are pain, swelling of the lid and diminished vision. Once the endophthalmitis sets in it is important to treat all the cases empirically with a combination of antibiotics and steroids from the beginning.

Steroids are given in endophthalmitis to reduce the inflammation of the tissues. The preferred route of administration is either by intravitreal injections, topical concentrations or oral route. Intravenous route of administration of steroids is not used in endophthalmitis.

Acute postoperative bacterial endophthalmitis occurs within 1-7 days after cataract surgery and the most important factor to prevent it is preoperative administration of 5% povidone iodine.

The various drugs,routes and surgical management used to treat endophthalmitis are as follows:

  • The mainstay of treatment is intravitreal injections of antibiotics.
                 First choice: Vancomycin 1 mg in 0.1 mL plus ceftazidime 2.25mg in 0.1ml.
                 Second choice: Vancomycin 1 mg in 0.1 mL plus amikacin 0.4mg in 0.1ml.
    If there is no improvement, a repeat intravitreal injection should be given after 48 hours
  • Topical Solutions of antibiotics are started immediately and used frequently
                 Vancomycin (50mg/ml) or cefazolin (50mg/ml)
                 Amikacin (20mg/ml) or tobramycin
  • Systemic antibiotics have a limited role in the treatment but are commonly used in practice.
  • Steroid therapy includes
                 Intravitreal injection of Dexamethasone(0.4mg in 0.1ml) which is started along with antibiotics.
                 Topical Dexamethasone (0.1%)
                 Oral steroids such as prednisolone are started after 24 hours of intensive antibiotic therapy.
  • Supportive therapy are
                 Cycloplegics such as Atropine 1%
                 Anti-Glaucoma drugs such as oral acetazolamide or timolol in patients with raised intraocular pressure
  • Vitrectomy- Pars Plana Vitrectomy is done if the patient does not improve with the above therapy in 48-72 hours or when the visual acuity is reduced to hand movements near the eye.

questions.text: For what purpose were knowledge, attitude, and practice (KAP) studies first used in India?
questions.solution:
Knowledge, attitude and practice (KAP) studies were first used in India to study family planning.

These studies help in evaluating the knowledge, attitude, and practices of a community. It also gives an educational diagnosis.

questions.text: A male patient presents with complaints of jaundice, loss of appetite, and weight loss for the past several months. After a full laboratory workup, a liver biopsy was performed which appeared as shown in the given image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows ground-glass hepatocytes which are a hallmark of chronic hepatitis B infection. 

These ground-glass hepatocytes are liver parenchymal cells that have an eosinophilic, granular, and glassy appearance on light microscopy. This appearance is due to the accumulation of HBsAg (hepatitis B surface antigen) in the smooth endoplasmic reticulum.

Liver biopsy findings in viral hepatitis:

Virus Liver Biopsy Findings
Hepatitis A Hepatocyte swelling, monocyte infiltration, Councilman bodies
Hepatitis B  Ground glass appearance 
Hepatitis C  Lymphoid aggregates with a focal area of macrovesicular steatosis 
Hepatitis D Similar to HBV 
Hepatitis E Patchy necrosis

questions.text: For which of the following diseases is soil not a reservoir?
questions.solution:
The main reservoir of the coccobacilli belonging to the genus Brucella that cause brucellosis are animals like sheep, cattle, horses, goats, whales, and dogs.

A reservoir is the environment (e.g. soil, humans, animals, water, etc.) where the infectious agent grows and multiplies (natural habitat) and from where it can be transmitted to a susceptible host.

A source is an animal, object, human or substance which acts as an immediate mode of transmission and may or may not be a part of the reservoir.

Option A: Coccidiomycosis is also called Valley fever and the causative fungi belong to the Coccidiodes. The main reservoir of this organism is soil.

Option B: Bacillus anthracis is a soil commensal and is also found on the hides and dried skins of infected animals.

Option C: The natural reservoir for the fungi causing mycetoma is soil.

questions.text: There is an outbreak of hookworm infection in your locality. On investigation, it is found that the outbreak is a result of open-air defecation. The district council decides to construct an RCA type of latrine in every household.  What is the optimum water seal required?
questions.solution:
The optimum water seal required for an RCA type of latrine is 2 – 2.5 cm.

It was designed by the Research-cum-Action Projects (RCA) in Environmental Sanitation of the Ministry of Health. Water seals aids in preventing flies and other organisms from reaching the waste. It also prevents the escape of odors and foul gases, eliminating the nuisance from the smell.

Features of RCA type of latrine
Location More than 15m away from the water source
Squatting plate Should be impervious and should allow for drainage of water
Pan Receives the nightsoil, urine, and washes water.
Trap Holds the water and provides the water seal. A good trap has an effective seal of around 2 – 2.5 cms.
Connecting pipe Present in indirect type and absent in direct type
Dug well Has to be changed after it is filled
Superstructure Built for privacy and shelter

questions.text: A person was brought dead and an autopsy was performed to find the cause of death. The following findings were noted on examination. What is the probable cause of death?
questions.solution:
The given autposy images are suggestive of throttling.

In throttling, the following mechanisms may lead to death:

  • Occlusion of blood supply to the blood to the brain - carotid arteries 
  • Occlusion of the airway - minor role
  • Carotid sinus pressure may result in vagus nerve stimulation resulting in cardiac arrest (vasovagal shock)

Other signs in deaths due to asphyxia:

  • Petechial hemorrhages in the face, eyebrows, eyelids, forehead, ears, conjunctiva, sclera
    • When they occur in the visceral pleura, they are called Tardieu’s spots 
  • Congested larynx with slight oozing
  • Marked venous congestion of internal organs
  • Emphysematous, congested  lungs with serosanguinous fluid exudates in alveoli
  • Dark-coloured blood due to accumulation of CO2

Option B: Strangulation is a very generalised term used to describe deaths due to violent asphyxia. Eg- ligature strangulation, throttling etc

Option C:  In the case of hanging, there will be a ligature mark, injury to the cervical spine etc.

Option D: In case of mugging the neck is compressed or squeezed by holding it between the crook of the elbow or knee. The attack is usually made from behind. Though a victim killed by this method shows signs of asphyxia and other struggle marks, the examination neck will not show any evidence of violence, as the compression was affected by the soft muscles of the arm or leg.

questions.text: A 1-year-old baby was brought by his mother with growth failure and developmental delay. Laboratory investigations revealed a hemoglobin of  8 g/dL and normal levels of vitamin B12 and B9. His peripheral smear is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with a peripheral smear showing hypersegmented neutrophils with normal vitamin B12 and B9 levels is suggestive of orotic aciduria.

Orotic aciduria is a rare autosomal recessive condition. It occurs due to an error in the de novo synthesis of pyrimidine resulting in the failure of conversion of orotic acid to uridine. As a result, there is increased excretion of orotic acid in urine. It is of two types:

  • Type I - deficiency of both orotate phosphoribosyl transferase and OMP decarboxylase (together called UMPsynthase)
  • Type II - deficiency of only orotidylate decarboxylase.

Children clinically present with megaloblastic anemia that is unresponsive to vitamin B12 and folic acid, failure to thrive, developmental delay, and intellectual disability.

Confirmation of the diagnosis requires an assay of the transferase and decarboxylase enzymes in the patient's red blood cells. Anemia responds well to the administration of uridine.

Other options:

Option A: Gout is a metabolic disease associated with hyperuricemia. It is characterized by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints and connective tissue. It usually presents as painful monoarthritis that mainly involves the metatarsophalangeal joints of the first toe.

Option B: Severe combined immune deficiency (SCID) occurs due to a deficiency in adenosine deaminase, an enzyme of purine metabolism. This results in the accumulation of adenosine metabolites. This causes premature cell death of B, T and NK cells. Children with SCID present with recurrent oral candidiasis, failure to thrive, diarrhea and interstitial pneumonitis.

Option D: Copper deficiency is usually seen in a condition called Menkes kinky hair syndrome. Children usually present with intellectual disability, hypocupremia, and decreased circulating ceruloplasmin.

questions.text: What is the dense zone of calcification seen at the metaphysis in scurvy?
questions.solution:
Dense zone of calcification at growing metaphysis seen in scurvy is known as Frankel's line.

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring/ Wimberger sign: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

questions.text: Which of the following is not expressed in the B-cell receptor complex?
questions.solution:
CD86 is a protein expressed on antigen-presenting cells, and not B-cell receptor complex. This protein provides costimulatory signals necessary for T-cell activation and survival.

B-cell receptor complex expresses the following:

  • CD79a and CD79b - essential for signal transduction through the antigen receptor
  • CD21 or CR2 - complement receptor (recognize complement products during innate immune response) and Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) receptor
  • CD40 - receives signals from helper T cells

Other B cell-associated markers are CD10 (CALLA), CD19, CD20, CD22, CD23.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most effective reversible method of contraception?
questions.solution:
The most effective reversible method of contraception among the given options is Norplant, which is a subdermal hormonal implant.

The most effective method of contraception overall is sterilization, which is one of the permament methods. Both methods belong to the first-tier category of contraceptives.

There are 2 types of subdermal implants:

  • Implanon (which has replaced Norplant I)
  • Norplant II

The implants work by inhibition of ovulation, endometrial atrophy, and thickening of cervical mucus. Implanon contains desogestrel and also reduces acne and osteoporosis.

The implants are inserted on the first day of the menstrual cycle, within 5 days of abortion, and 3 weeks after the delivery. The woman needs to use barrier contraception or abstain in the first 7 days of insertion.

The image below shows an implanon:

 

The image given below shows the insertion of a subdermal implant:

 

Advantages of implants:

  • Long-acting with sustained effect
  • Good compliance 
  • Coital-independent with no nuisance of daily oral or frequent injections
  • Failure rate - 0.2 and 1.3 per 100 woman-years
  • Implanon reduces acne and osteoporosis.

Disadvantages of implants:

  • Breakthrough bleeding
  • Irregular cycles
  • Amenorrhoea 
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Local infection
  • Requires insertion and removal with nonbiodegradable capsules
  • Expensive.

Related Pearl: Classification Of Contraceptives Based On Effectiveness

Category Failure rate in first year Contraceptive
First tier  < 2 % IUCD, Implants, Sterilization
Second tier  3-9 % Hormonal - oral, injected, transdermal patches, transvaginal rings
Third tier  10-20 % Barrier, Fertility awareness method
Fourth tier  21-30 % Spermicidal preparations

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases and Stroke?

choices.text: No separate centres for stroke, DM and cancer
Implementation in over 10 districts in 5 states
Subcentre has facility for diagnosis and treatment

questions.solution:
District hospital has specialized facilities for the National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases and Stroke (NPCDCS).

The NPCDCS has separate components for cancer and other non-communicable diseases like diabetes, cardiovascular diseases, and stroke. It has been implemented in over 100 districts in 21 states.

At the subcentre level under NPCDCS, screening and referral are done.

Note: The National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases and Stroke(NPCDCS) has been changed to the National Programme for Prevention and Control of Non-Communicable Diseases(NP-NCD) to include new diseases and new health initiatives.

The new diseases included in the NP-NCD are: 

  • Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease
  • Chronic Kidney disease
  • Asthma and Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
  • ST elevation myocardial infarction

questions.text: Which of the following patients can be diagnosed with diabetes mellitus?

choices.text: A patient with RBS of 210 mg/dl
A patient with FBS of 125 mg/dl and 2-hour PPBS of 199 mg/dl
A patient with symptoms of diabetes and RBS of 192 mg/dl

questions.solution:
The patient with HbA1c ≥ 6.5 % can be diagnosed with diabetes mellitus as this is an independent criterion for diagnosis.

Related Pearl: ADA criteria for Diagnosis of Diabetes mellitus

Any one of the following:

  • Symptoms of diabetes plus Random Blood Glucose concentration ≥ 200 mg/dL.
  • Fasting plasma glucose ≥ 126 mg/dL. Fasting is defined as no caloric intake for at least 8 hours.
  • Haemoglobin A1c ≥6.5%
  • 2-hour plasma glucose ≥ 200 mg/dL during an oral glucose tolerance test.

Note: In the absence of unequivocal hyperglycemia and acute metabolic decompensation, these criteria should be confirmed by repeat testing on a different day.

questions.text: If the total body water is 60% of the body weight, what are the proportions of ECF and ICF?
questions.solution:
When expressed as the percentage of body weight, 40% of body weight is in ICF (2/3rd of 60%), and 20% of body weight is in ECF (1/3rd of 60%).

The 60-40-20 rule is: 60% of body weight is water, 40% is ICF, and 20% is ECF.

Related Pearl: Body Fluids Compartments

  • In ECF, a third specialized compartment, called the transcellular compartment (not shown in flow chart), is quantitatively small and includes the cerebrospinal, pleural, peritoneal, pericardial, synovial, intraocular and digestive fluids. Altogether it constitutes about 1-2 L.
  • The ECF volume/intracellular fluid volume ratio is larger in infants and children than it is in adults, but the absolute volume of ECF in children is, of course, smaller than in adults. Therefore, dehydration develops more rapidly and is frequently more severe in children.
  • All solutes and water that enter or leave the body do so via the ECF.
  • The ICF and ECF are in osmotic equilibrium. Water moves between these compartments only when an osmotic pressure gradient exists.
  • Equilibration of ICF and ECF osmolality occurs primarily by shifts in water and not shifts in solutes.

questions.text: Which of the following is connected to the structure marked as A in the image below?
questions.solution:
The structure marked A is the splenium of the corpus callosum and it is connected to the striate cortex.

The body of the corpus callosum arches posteriorly and ends as the thickened posterior portion called the splenium. The fibers from the splenium form the forceps major and arch backward into the occipital lobe (striate cortex).

The hippocampus is not connected directly to the splenium, but situated inferior to the splenium.

The image given below shows the parts of the corpus callosum.

Related Pearl: Corpus Callosum

Parts of the corpus callosum:

  • Rostrum: connects frontal lobes (eg: orbitofrontal cortex)
  • Genu: connects frontal lobes. It is the anterior-most part.
  • Trunk or Body: connects temporal lobes.
  • Splenium: connects the two occipital lobes. It is the thickest part.

Note: Isthmus is a part which separates the body from splenium, some books mention it as a part.

  • The fibers of the genu curve forward into frontal lobes and form forceps minor.
  • The fibers of the trunk extend laterally as radiation of corpus callosum.
  • The fibers from the trunk and the splenium which form the lateral wall of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle constitute the tapetum.
  • The fibers from the splenium arching backwards into the occipital lobe form forceps major.

questions.text: Which of the following structures do not form the hilar shadow in a chest X-ray?
questions.solution:
Lower lobe veins are not part of the radiological hilum.

The radiological hilum is formed by the pulmonary arteries (and their bifurcations), the upper lobe veins, and the bronchi. The lower lobe pulmonary veins, which pass inferiorly, form no component of the normal hilar shadow. Lymph nodes only contribute to the shadow when enlarged.

questions.text: Plasma membrane in eukaryotes is made up of all except _______
questions.solution:
Plasma membrane in eukaryotes does not contain triglycerides.

The plasma membrane is composed almost entirely of proteins and lipids. The major lipids include:

  • Phospholipids: Lecithin, cephalin, phosphatidylserine
  • Sphingolipids: Sphingomyelin
  • Cholesterol

questions.text: As per revised 2014 WHO  guidelines which of the following pneumonia case is safe to treat at home?
questions.solution:
The revised 2014 WHO guidelines states that it is safe to treat chest indrawing pneumonia at home.

However, a child who is HIV positive and has chest indrawing needs to be referred for inpatient treatment.

Only those children who have the following general danger signs are classified as having “severe pneumonia” and need to be referred to a higher level (hospital admission):

  • Not able to drink
  • Persistent vomiting
  • Convulsions lethargic or unconscious
  • Stridor in a calm child
  • Severe malnutrition

questions.text: Which of the following is false about live vaccines?

choices.text: Simultaneous administration of  two live vaccines should be done in the same syringe
Two live vaccines can be administered simultaneously
Immuno-compromised state poses a contraindication to live vaccines
Live vaccines contain both major and minor antigens

questions.solution:
Simultaneous administration of vaccines is defined as administering more than one vaccine on the same clinic day, at different anatomic sites. They are not combined in the same syringe.

Simultaneous administration of the most widely used live and inactivated vaccines does not result in decreased antibody responses or increased rates of adverse reaction. However, in children with functional or anatomic asplenia pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV13) and Menactra brand meningococcal conjugate vaccines should not be administered at the same visit; separate these vaccines by at least 4 weeks.

Advantages of simultaneous administration of vaccines:

  • The organisms multiply in the host and thus, the antigenic dose is larger than what is injected.
  • They have all the major and minor antigenic components.

Live vaccines should not be administered to those with an immunocompromised state, since they may cause severe systemic disease by way of viremia/bacteriemia.

Note: If live vaccines are not given simultaneously, they must be spaced as follows-

  • The administration of two live parenteral vaccines or live intranasal influenza vaccines must be separated by at least 4 weeks (28 days).
  • If two live vaccines are given less than 4 weeks apart, the second vaccine should be repeated in four weeks. This is because the live vaccine given first can interfere with the second vaccine, and the person may not develop active immunity to the second vaccine.

Injected and intranasal live vaccines are not believed to have an effect on live oral vaccines. Live oral vaccines may be given at any time before or after administration of live injected or intranasal vaccines.

questions.text: All of the following are effective in the management of patients with ventricular tachycardia except:
questions.solution:
Carotid sinus massage will be effective only in supraventricular tachycardias but not in ventricular tachycardias. This is because it acts by increasing the AV node block which does not play any role in the pathogenesis of ventricular tachycardia.

Hence, AV node blocking maneuvers (carotid sinus massage, valsalva) and drugs (adenosine) are not used in the management of VT.

Related Pearl: Difference between VT and SVT with aberrancy

questions.text: A professional wrestler presents to your OPD with the deformity shown below. What is the most likely cause of the same?
questions.solution:
The image shows a cauliflower ear deformity, which is likely due to auricular hematoma. 

Auricular hematoma is a collection of blood between the auricular cartilage and its perichondrium. If left untreated, the extravasated blood may clot and then organize, resulting in a typical deformity called cauliflower ear. It is also called pugilistic or boxer’s ear. 

It is often seen in boxers, wrestlers, and rugby players due to blunt trauma.

Treatment comprises of aspiration of the hematoma under strict aseptic precautions and a pressure dressing, to prevent reaccumulation. Aspiration may need to be repeated. If aspiration fails, incision and drainage should be done. All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotics.

Related Pearl: Eponyms of the ear

Eponym

Description

Boxer’s/ Cauliflower ear

Organized hematoma of pinna

Surfer’s ear

Exostosis

Swimmer’s ear

Diffuse otitis externa

questions.text: When providing CPR to an adult, what ratio of chest compressions to rescue breaths would you provide if there were 2 rescuers?
questions.solution:
During cardiopulmonary resuscitation of adults, the ratio of chest compression to rescue breaths is 30:2 irrespective of the number of rescuers.

In infants and children, the ratio is 30:2 for a single-rescuer and 15:2 if 2 or more rescuers are present.

 

Related Pearl: High quality CPR for adults

  • Push hard: 5-6cm depth
  • Push fast: 100-120/min frequency
  • Allow for complete chest recoil
  • Minimize interruptions in compressions <10 seconds
  • Avoid excessive ventilation
  • Rotate compressor every 2 min or earlier if fatigued
  • If no advanced airway, 30:2 compression-ventilation ratio

Attempt to improve CPR quality if :

  • Quantitative waveform capnography - PETCO2 <10mmHg, 
  • Intra-arterial pressure - If relaxation phase (diastolic) pressure <20mmHg

questions.text: A 45-year-old fisherman presents with pain and a lesion in his hand similar to what is shown in the image.  What is the causative organism for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a raised, well-circumscribed, violaceous lesion with the absence of pus. Thus, it is erysipeloid which is a skin infection caused by Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae.

Erysipeloid usually occurs on the fingers by direct inoculation at the site of a cut or abrasion, in people who handle animals, fish or animal products. Pain, swelling and erythema develop and the condition has been called seal finger and whale finger. Pus is usually absent at the infection site, which helps differentiate it from staphylococcal and streptococcal skin infections. It resolves without treatment in 3-4 weeks. 

Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae is a slender, non-motile, non-sporing Gram positive bacillus. It is catalase, oxidase, and indole negative. It causes disease in multiple land animals like swine, turkeys and sheep. 

Note: Erysipelas is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes. It presents as erythematous raised lesions with sharply demarcated edges.

questions.text: A 40-year old man is brought to the emergency room with a stab injury to his chest. On examination, the patient is found to be hemodynamically unstable. His neck veins are engorged and heart sounds are muffled. Which of the following statements about the patient is false?

choices.text: Cardiac tamponade is likely to be present
The entry wound is sealed on all 4 sides with an occlusive dressing if pneumothorax is suspected
eFAST is done to confirm blood in pericardial sac

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hemodynamic instability and muffled heart sounds are suggestive of cardiac tamponade. The entry wound is sealed on only 3 sides with an occlusive dressing if a pneumothorax is suspected.

When there is a pneumothorax with a sucking wound, the immediate step is to cover the wound with gauze pieces and tape on 3 sides.

As the patient breathes in, the dressing occludes the wound, preventing air from entering into the thoracic cavity. During exhalation, the open end of the dressing allows air to escape from the pleural space. This is known as a flutter-valve effect.

Following this, a chest tube is inserted away from the site of the wound.

Cardiac tamponade must be diﬀerentiated from tension pneumothorax in a patient with hemodynamic instability and distended neck veins.

Cardiac tamponade is characterized by Beck’s triad:

  • Muffled heart sounds
  • Distended neck veins
  • Hypotension

Tension pneumothorax is characterized by absent breath sounds and hyper resonance on percussion on the affected side. These are not present in a patient with cardiac tamponade.

Diagnosis of cardiac tamponade can be done by eFAST which shows fluid in the pericardial sac. 

  • Definitive management - emergency thoracotomy or sternotomy

questions.text: In a clinical trial to evaluate a drug, randomisation was done before starting the trial. What is the purpose behind this?

choices.text: The two groups will be similar in prognostic factors
The clinician has no control over the allocation of participants in each group
The clinician can predict in advance which treatment the subjects will receive
The sample may be referenced to a known population

questions.solution:
The main purpose behind randomisation is to eliminate selection bias.

In an RCT, participants are randomly assigned to a study group or a control group. It is done only after obtaining consent. It removes both known and unknown confounding factors.

The heart of a randomized controlled trial (RCT) is randomisation. This allows comparability between the study and the control population.

Related Pearl: Randomized Controlled Trials

Randomized controlled trials are a type of experimental studies.

Types

  • Clinical trials
  • Preventive trials
  • Risk factor trials
  • Cessation experiments
  • Trial of etiological agents
  • Evaluation of health services

General Design of an RCT

Steps of an RCT

  • Drawing up a protocol
  • Selecting reference and experimental population
  • Randomization
  • Manipulation or intervention
  • Follow-up
  • Assessment of outcome.

questions.text: A postmenopausal lady came to the clinic with complaints of breast pain and a lump in her right breast for the past 2 months. On examination, the breast appears as shown in the image. What is the most likely cause for this finding?
questions.solution:
In the given image, the orange peel-like appearance, also called as peau d’orange is caused by cutaneous lymphatic edema, due to the obstruction of subcutaneous lymphatics. It is the hallmark of inflammatory carcinoma.

Option A: Infiltration of Cooper’s ligaments leads to dimpling of the skin.

Option C: Infiltration of the lactiferous ducts leads to nipple retraction.

Cancer-en-cuirasse is an aggressive form of cancer, where there is cutaneous and subcutaneous infiltration of the cancer cells.

Note: While Peau d’orange indicates skin involvement, dimpling of the skin and nipple retraction do not indicate skin involvement.

questions.text: Fingerprinting (FINDER ) involves recording prints of 8 fingers. Which finger pair is excluded ?
questions.solution:
The finger pair excluded by FINDER are little finger.

Fingerprint reader is a computerized automatic fingerprint reading system which can record each fingerprint data in half second. Prints of eight fingers are recorded excluding little fingers. The light reflected from a fingerprint can be measured and converted  to digital data which is classified codified and stored in the computer.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the airway adjunct shown in the image given below?

choices.text: It is used only in unconscious patients
Prevents falling back of tongue post-extubation
Prevents tongue bite during seizure activity
Can be used in patients with central facial fracture

questions.solution:
The image shows nasopharyngeal airway and its insertion. The true statement is that it is used to prevent falling back of tongue post-extubation especially in obese patients.

Nasopharyngeal airways are less stimulating than oropharyngeal airways as it bypasses the gag reflex. Thus, it can be used in conscious patients as well.

It does not prevent tongue bite unlike the oropharyngeal airway which has a bite block. It can prevent falling back of the tongue in patients with seizures.

It is contraindicated in

  • Basilar skull fractures, central facial fractures, CSF rhinorrhea - risk of meningitis
  • Patients on anticoagulants, coagulopathies, epistaxis - risk of bleeding
  • Relatively contraindicated in pregnancy (increased vascularity leading to bleeding), deformity of the nose.

questions.text: Which of the following combinations should be avoided while treating a patient with angina?
questions.solution:
Verapamil and β-blockers have additive effects on inhibiting SA node and AV conduction, the combination should be avoided to prevent severe bradycardia and conduction block. These agents can also have additive effects on decreasing left ventricular function which could seriously impair cardiac output in a patient with heart failure.

Diltiazem can be combined with beta-blockers in patients with normal ventricular function and no conduction disturbances.

Amlodipine and β-blockers have complementary actions on coronary blood supply and myocardial oxygen demands. Whereas the former decreases blood pressure and dilates coronary arteries, the latter slows the heart rate and decreases contractility.

questions.text: A patient presented with acute onset of weakness of the left arm which resolved completely in 10 days. He is known to have mitral stenosis, hypertension and dyslipidemia.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with mitral stenosis and acute onset weakness of the left arm is most likely to have had an embolic stroke, which is a type of ischemic stroke. Embolic strokes tend to occur suddenly with maximum neurologic deficit present at onset.

Mitral stenosis is known to cause atrial fibrillation and is a common cause of cardioembolic stroke.

Transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a temporary, focal neurological deficit of sudden onset (stroke-like symptoms) lasting for less than 24 hours. This occurs due to focal ischemia of the brain, retina or cochlea. Most TIAs last for less than 1 hour to a few minutes.

There is a high risk of developing an ischemic stroke after a TIA, especially for the first 3 months following a TIA.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman was brought to the casualty in a drowsy state with complaints of bleeding PV  associated with abdominal pain and a history of amenorrhoea for 8 weeks. On examination, BP was 90/60 mmHg, PR was 140 bpm, and UPT was positive. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of ruptured ectopic pregnancy which must be immediately managed with simultaneous resuscitation and laparotomy. On laparotomy, salpingectomy is the definitive surgery. 

Diagnosis of ruptured ectopic pregnancy is made based on clinical features:

  • Amenorrhoea for 6-8 weeks followed by bleeding PV
  • Abdominal pain 
  • Hemodynamically unstable 
  • Urine pregnancy test - positive

Surgical treatment of ectopic pregnancy includes salpingectomy or salpingostomy, performed either through laparoscopy or laparotomy.

Management of suspected ruptured ectopic pregnancy consists of initial resuscitation and stabilization, followed by point-of-care ultrasound (FAST) to identify intraperitoneal free fluid and surgical exploration. 

Laparotomy is done for hemodynamically unstable patients with ruptured ectopic pregnancies. Salpingectomy is the treatment of choice and is done with preservation of the ipsilateral ovary and its vascular supply. 

For patients wishing to preserve future fertility, if the contralateral fallopian tube is damaged, salpingostomy is preferred. However, salpingostomy may result in inadequate evacuation of the products of conception and a recurrence of symptoms. Therefore, after a patient undergoes salpingostomy, it is important check the β-hCG level on a weekly basis to ensure that it reaches zero.

The image given below shows a laparoscopic visualization of a tubal pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following fluids have the highest daily secretion of potassium?
questions.solution:
The highest daily secretion of K+ is into the saliva.

In the process of formation of saliva, Na+ and Cl- are reabsorbed from the saliva, and K+ and HCO3- are secreted into the saliva.

Note: The highest concentration of K+ is in the rectal fluid.

questions.text: An ENT senior resident posted in a remote village comes across a patient in whom he suspects otosclerosis. Which of the following tests can be used if he wants to clinically confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Gelle’s is a tuning fork test done to clinically confirm otosclerosis in the olden days.

It is based on the fact that in a normal ear if pressure is increased in the external ear the stapes footplate will get medialized and will stop conducting sound. But, in an ear with otosclerosis of the footplate, there will be no movements and the patient will continue to hear the sound. Thus, Gelle’s test is considered positive in normal persons and in those with sensorineural hearing loss. It is negative when the ossicular chain is fixed or disconnected.

Stenger’s test is done to rule out malingering.

Schwabach is a tuning fork test that compares the bone conduction of the patient with that of the examiner.

Rinne’s is a tuning fork test that compares bone conduction with air conduction.

questions.text: The following image depicts:
questions.solution:
The given image shows raised, brownish thread-like lesions in the interdigital distribution (burrows), typically seen in scabies.

Scabies is an ectoparasitic infection caused in humans by Sarcoptes scabiei. It is transmitted by close personal contact. Pruritis with nocturnal exacerbation and contact cases within a family should raise the suspicion of scabies. Typical locations of lesions are the finger webs, the flexor surfaces of the wrists, the elbows, the axillae, the buttocks and genitalia and the breasts of women (Circle of Hebra). In adults, the face is often spared. Pruritic papules and nodules on male genitalia and breasts serve as valuable diagnostic clues in the absence of burrows. 

Dermoscopy of the burrows shows jet‐with‐contrail appearance. Microscopy of scraping from burrows can be done to demonstrate mites.

A single overnight application of 5% permethrin cream from neck to toe in adults and from head to toe in children is the drug of choice for the treatment of scabies in all ages including infants (at least 2 months old) and pregnant women. All family members, even if asymptomatic, need to be treated simultaneously for this condition to prevent reinfection. Oral ivermectin can also be used.

questions.text: The false statement regarding the method shown in the image is

choices.text: Can be continued in babies >2500 g also

questions.solution:
The image shows Kangaroo mother care. It is for discontinued for babies above 2500 grams.
Principles of Kangaroo Mother Care

  • SSC - Skin to Skin contact
  • Exclusive Breastfeeding
  • Early home  discharge and followup.


KMC can even be done on mothers that are on IV fluids, CPAP or even ventilators if they are hemodynamically stable.

questions.text: A young couple being treated for infertility require donor semen for artificial insemination. Which of the following is the likely cause of infertility here?

choices.text: Presence of antisperm antibodies in the cervical mucucs

questions.solution:
Artificial insemination with donor semen is done in cases of infertility where the husband has azoospermia.

Azoospermia is defined as a complete absence of sperms. Hence artificial insemination with the husband's/partner's semen cannot be performed.

Indications for artificial insemination with husband's/partner's semen are:

  1. Chronic medical disorder
  2. Oligospermia after sperm washout
  3. Impotence
  4. Premature and retrograde ejaculation
  5. Hypospadias
  6. Antisperm antibodies in cervical mucus
  7. Unexplained infertility- direct intraperitoneal insemination (DIPI) is done
  8. HIV-positive male or female
  9. X-Y fractionation of sperms for sex selection in cases of genetic and chromosomal abnormalities

Indications for artificial insemination with donor semen are:

  1. Azoospermia
  2. Uncorrectable immunological factors
  3. Genetic disease in husband/partner
  4. Chronic ill health

Sperms can be frozen and used later for artificial insemination e.g. if the husband requires to undergo radiotherapy or chemotherapy, or if the husband is a frequent traveler and is not available at the time of ovulation.

Artificial insemination techniques include:

  • Intrauterine Insemination (IUI)
  • Intrafallopian-tube Insemination
  • Intracervical Insemination
  • Direct Intraperitoneal Insemination (DIPI)

Steps required to do artificial insemination are:

  1. The semen is washed to remove abnormal sperms, debris, and seminal plasma containing antibodies. It is concentrated, and its quality is improved by the 'swim up technique' or by the use of the Percoll gradient.
  2. Semen with normal sperms and good motility is obtained.
  3. Around the time of ovulation, semen obtained is inseminated into the female genital tract. About 0.5 ml of semen is injected 36 hours after hCG injection when the ovarian follicle reaches 20 mm.

questions.text: An elderly woman was brought to the hospital with a history of severe loin pain for the past 7 hours. Ultrasound of the kidney reveals a 2.5 cm renal stone. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for renal calculi of size >2cm is percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL). 

In PCNL, endoscopic instruments are passed into the kidney using a percutaneous technique, and stones are removed. PCNL is also indicated in:

  • Staghorn calculi
  • Multiple stones
  • Proximal ureteral stones >1 cm

Complications of percutaneous nephrolithotomy include hemorrhage, perforation of the collecting system, and of the colon or pleural cavity.

Another approach for the management of renal stones is ureteroscopic removal(URS) or retrograde intra-renal surgery (RIRS). In URS, stones are removed via a retrograde approach using a dormia basket, or a Holmium YAG laser is used to break the stones. 

If PCNL or URS fails, open or laparoscopic pyelolithotomy or nephrolithotomy is done.

The image below summarizes how the Dormia basket works with ureteroscopy.

Related Pearl: Management of renal and ureteric calculi

ESWL: Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy

PCNL: Percutaneous nephrolithotomy

URS: Ureteroscopic retrieval of stones

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presented to the emergency room with abdominal pain and fever for the last 48 hours. She has been using a Cu T 380A for contraception for the past 8 years. On examination, cervical motion tenderness was present. What is the most likely organism to have caused her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of PID in an IUCD user. The most common organism causing this condition is Actinomyces. It has been reported in 7% of IUCD users if the device is worn for more than 2 years.

This emphasizes the need for strict asepsis during insertion of the device and the need for strict follow up of women wearing these devices.

Organisms causing PID are:

Sexually transmitted:

  • Chlamydia (most common)
  • Gonococcus
  • Mycoplasma
  • Trichomonas

Pyogenic Aerobes:

  • Staphylococci
  • Streptococci
  • E Coli

Anaerobes:

  • Bacteroides fragilis
  • Peptostreptococcus 
  • Clostridium 
  • Actinomyces (most common in IUD users)

Other:

  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis

questions.text: Polychromatic lustre is seen in:
questions.solution:
• Polychromatic lustre is seen in complicated cataracts like posterior cortical cataract.
  • Complicated cataracts occur due to some other inflammatory or degenerative pathology of the eye like iridocyclitis, ciliary body tumors, degenerative myopia, etc.
  • If the posterior segment is affected, a characteristic opacification begins in the posterior part of the cortex.
  • In a slit lamp examination, these opacities have a characteristic rainbow display of colors called polychromatic lustre.

questions.text: What is the optimum temperature for storage of RBCs collected in preservatives?
questions.solution:
The optimum temperature for storage of packed RBCs and whole blood collected in preservatives is +2° to +6° C. This temperature maintains the viability of the cells and prevents bacterial contamination.

Blood component  Storage temperature Shelf-life

questions.text: A patient with pallor and pathological fracture is diagnosed with multiple myeloma. Which of the following is not a kidney finding of such patients?
questions.solution:
Wire-loop lesions are seen in systemic lupus erythematosus and not in multiple myeloma. 

Renal insufficiency occurs in half the patients with multiple myeloma and several factors are responsible for it. They develop acute kidney injury with ologuria and chronic kidney disease. Tubular casts, amyloidosis, and renal tubular necrosis are all described in the myeloma kidneys.

Features of myeloma kidney: 

  • Bence–Jones proteinuria and cast nephropathy - The main cause of renal dysfunction is related to Bence–Jones (light-chain) proteinuria. Ig light chains are directly toxic to epithelial cells. Bence-Jones proteins form large, histologically distinct tubular casts that obstruct the tubular lumens and induce a characteristic inflammatory reaction (light-chain cast nephropathy).
  • Amyloidosis of AL type, formed from free light chains (usually of λ type)
  • Light-chain deposition disease - light chains (usually of κ type) deposit in the glomerular basement membrane and mesangium causing a glomerulopathy and in tubular basement membranes, which may cause tubulointerstitial nephritis.
  • Hypercalcemia - Nephrocalcinosis

questions.text: The histological section of an intracranial space-occupying lesion resected from a  patient is given below. Which of the following tumors shows this pattern?
questions.solution:
The histological image shows fried egg appearance of cells and is seen in oligodendroglioma.

Oligodendroglioma is an infiltrating glioma comprised of cells that resemble oligodendrocytes. It commonly occurs in the fourth and fifth decades. The lesion is found mostly in the cerebral hemispheres, with a pre­dilection for white matter. 

The tumor is composed of sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm giving a fried egg appearance. Tumor cells infiltrating the cerebral cortex often collect around the neurons (perineuronal satellitosis).

Fried eggs in pathology:

  • Oligodendroglioma on histopathology
  • Hairy cell leukemia on bone marrow biopsy
  • Seminoma / Dysgerminoma on light microscopy
  • Mycoplasma pneumonia fried egg colonies on Eaton agar

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: What is the most common site of syphilitic aneurysms?
questions.solution:
Syphilitic aneurysms most commonly involves the ascending aorta.

Late-stage syphilis causes obliterative endarteritis of vasa vasorum of the aorta. This leads to ischemic injury of the aortic media resulting in aneurysmal dilation.

questions.text: Double diffusion in two dimensions is called as ___________.
questions.solution:
Double diffusion in two dimensions is called the Ouchterlony procedure. Ex: Elek’s test for testing toxigenicity in diphtheria bacilli. 

The images below show the different types of immunodiffusion.

questions.text: Which of the following does not require 5’ capping?
questions.solution:
tRNA of Alanine does not require 5’ capping.

Capping process protects the 5′ end of mRNA from the action of exonucleases and polyadenylation protects the 3′ end of the mRNA. All mRNA, snRNA, and siRNA undergo this process, but tRNA are comparatively stable and do not require a capping at the 5’ end.

Note: rRNAs also do not require 5' capping.

questions.text: Fluoroacetate is a component of pesticides. Which of the following metabolic pathways is inhibited by this compound?
questions.solution:
Fluoroacetate inhibits the TCA cycle enzyme aconitase.

Fluoroacetyl CoA condenses with oxaloacetate to form fluorocitrate which inhibits aconitase, causing citrate to accumulate. This way it inhibits TCA cycle enzyme non-competitively.

Sources of fluoroacetate exposure:

  • Fluoroacetate in some plants
  • Fluorinated compounds (anticancer agents, industrial chemicals, and pesticides) are metabolized to fluoroacetate.

Related Pearl: Steps involved in TCA cycle

Step 1

Acetyl CoA + Oxaloacetate → Citrate

     (2C  + 4C  =   6C)

Enzyme: Citrate Synthase

Irreversible, Exothermic reaction
Step 2

Citrate → Cis –aconitate  → Isocitrate 

( 6C    →          6C →             6C)

Enzyme:   Aconitase

Cofactor:   Fe2+

The Reaction occurs in 2 steps:         

1st step:  Dehydration      

2nd step:  Rehydration

Inhibited by: Fluoroacetate (Non- Competitive)
Step 3

Isocitrate →[Oxalosuccinate]→α- Keto glutarate

        (6C) →         [6C]         →         (5C)

Enzyme:  Isocitrate Dehydrogenase

Cofactor:   Mn2+ or Mg2+

Reaction:  Oxidative  Decarboxylation

Intermediate:   Oxalosuccinate [ Unstable]

Release:    1 NADH and CO2
Step 4

α- Keto glutarate → Succcinyl Co A 

       (5C             →         4C)

Enzyme: α- Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase(Multienzyme complex)

Reaction:  Oxidative Decarboxylation

Inhibited by: Arsenite  (Non – Competitive)

Physiologically unidirectional step.

Release: 1 NADH and CO2
Step 5

Succinyl- CoA  → Succinate

      ( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Thiokinase

Cofactor: Mg2+

Release:  1 ATP / GTP

Substrate level phosphorylation
Step 6

Succinate  →   Fumarate

( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Dehydrogenase (Part of 2nd complex ETC)

Cofactor:  FAD and Fe-S protein 

The only enzyme of TCA cycle attached to the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Inhibited by: Malonate ( competitive)

Release: FADH2
Step 7

Fumarate  →   Malate

( 4C         →     4C )

Enzyme:  Fumarate Hydratase

Reaction: Hydration
Step 8

Malate  →  Oxaloacetate  

( 4C     →        4C )

Enzyme:  Malate Dehydrogenase

Release:  1 NADH

Oxaloacetate is regenerated.

questions.text: Spot the wrongly matched arthropod and disease.
questions.solution:
Blackflies (Simulium) are the vector for onchocerciasis and not Chaga's disease.

An arthropod or an invertebrate that transmits infection is called a vector. It transmits infection by:

  • Inoculation into or through the skin or mucous membrane
  • Biting
  • Deposit of infective materials on skin or food or other objects

Note: Chagas disease is transmitted by the reduviid bugs or kissing bugs or triatomines.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an adverse effect of escitalopram?
questions.solution:
Sialorrhoea is not an adverse effect of escitalopram.

Escitalopram is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) mainly used to treat major depressive disorder or generalized anxiety disorder.

Nausea is the commonest side effect of SSRIs as they target the 5HT3 receptor.

Vivid dreams may occur because the drug suppresses REM sleep (the stage of dream), hence when patients eventually fall into REM sleep it may be more intense. 

Anorgasmia is the persistent inability to achieve orgasm despite responding to sexual stimulation. A proposed mechanism of escitalopram causing sexual dysfunction involves stimulation of the 5HT2C receptors.

questions.text: A woman with menorrhagia is diagnosed with uterine fibroids. Prior to starting treatment, you want to check if she is premenopausal. On which day of the menstrual cycle will you estimate her FSH levels?

choices.text: On day 2-5 after last menstrual period
On day 11-14 after last menstrual period

questions.solution:
The follicular stimulating hormone (FSH) level is studied on day 2–5 after the last menstrual period to detect the premenopausal stage.

It is a period of 3–4 years before menopause and is associated with mild ovarian hormonal deficiency leading to menstrual disorders, especially menorrhagia.

The climacteric phase is the phase of waning of ovarian activity. It begins 2 to 3 years before menopause and may continue 2-5 years after menopause. It marks the transition from active to inactive ovarian function and involves physical, sexual, and psychological adjustments.

The predictors of approaching menopause include:

  • A fall in the level of inhibin B and a corresponding rise in FSH level
  • A fall in the level of anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) - This is a better marker of ovarian reserve and can be tested on any day of the cycle.

questions.text: A male baby born at term from uncomplicated delivery develops respiratory distress shortly after birth. The chest x-ray shows a diffuse ground-glass appearance of lung fields. Surfactant replacement and mechanical ventilation fail to improve hypoxemia. There is a history of death of a term male sibling at 1 month of age due to respiratory distress. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of respiratory distress and no response to surfactant therapy in a newborn and a family history of sibling death point toward a diagnosis of neonatal pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP).

It is a disorder characterized by intra-alveolar accumulation of pulmonary surfactant due to abnormal surfactant production or impaired clearance by alveolar macrophages. Inherited PAP occurs due to the dysfunction of various surfactant proteins.

Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis is classified into primary and secondary PAP. Primary pulmonary alveolar proteinosis is caused due to disruption of granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF) signaling. Secondary PAP is caused due to several different diseases that reduce alveolar macrophage number or function.

In the neonatal period, the disease may manifest as a severe respiratory failure whereas in older children it has an insidious onset of chronic interstitial lung disease. Infants present with symptoms of dyspnea, fatigue, cough, weight loss, chest pain, or hemoptysis.

Chest x-ray shows diffuse alveolointerstitial infiltrates presenting as ground-glass opacities. Lung biopsy is the gold standard investigation to diagnose PAP. Latex agglutination tests for the presence of anti–GM-CSF antibodies in BAL fluid or blood can also be done. They are highly sensitive and specific for the autoimmune forms of alveolar proteinosis.

The disease is progressive and is refractory to surfactant replacement therapy. Neonates with severe respiratory failure require mechanical ventilation and can also be treated with extracorporeal membrane oxygenation. Neonatal intensive care interventions and lung transplantation have been successful in a few cases. A total lung lavage is a therapeutic option for patients with childhood PAP. Subcutaneous or inhaled administration of recombinant GM-CSF may improve pulmonary function in some adults with later-onset PAP. 

Other options:

Option B: Meconium aspiration syndrome (MAS) presents immediately after birth, with features of respiratory distress due to aspiration of meconium in utero, resulting in airway obstruction. Most cases improve well with supportive care and mechanical ventilation. 

Option C: Hyaline membrane disease occurs in premature infants due to surfactant deficiency. Distress ensues within a few minutes of birth. If untreated, it may result in respiratory failure. Surfactant replacement therapy and mechanical ventilation will greatly improve the condition.

Option D: Transient tachypnea of the newborn is self-limiting tachypnea occurring in full-term infants due to reduced clearance of fetal lung fluid. Treatment is mainly supportive.

Related Pearl: Radiologic features of the major respiratory distress disorders in newborns

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia

  • Mediastinal shift
  • Bowel loops in the left hemithorax

 

Respiratory Distress Syndrome

  • Low lung volume
  • Symmetric ground-glass opacity (reticulogranular pattern)
  • Air bronchogram
  • White-out lung (severe disease)

Chest radiograph (A) on Day 2: shows reticulogranular opacities throughout both lungs with prominent air bronchograms. The cardiac silhouette is preserved and both lungs are hypoaerated.

Chest radiograph (B) on Day 9 (untreated): shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

 Meconium Aspiration Syndrome

  • Hyperinflation
  • Patchy infiltrates
  • Coarse streaking

questions.text: A man presented with severe pain over his foot after an RTA. Examination revealed tenderness and swelling over the dorsum of his mid-foot. X-ray showed a displaced fracture of the neck of the talus. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and x-ray showing a fracture of the neck of the talus point to a diagnosis of aviator's fracture.

These fractures most commonly occur following a high-energy injury causing forced dorsiflexion with axial load. They can be further classified using Hawkin's classification:

  • Type I - Undisplaced
  • Type II - Subtalar dislocation
  • Type III - Subtalar and tibiotalar dislocation
  • Type IV - Subtalar, tibiotalar, and talonavicular dislocation

Undisplaced fractures are managed conservatively in a short leg cast for 8-12 weeks and a non-weight bearing cast for 6 weeks. Hawkin's type II-IV are managed by open reduction with internal fixation (ORIF).

The below image shows the Hawkins classification of talar neck fractures.
