questions.text: A pregnant woman at 10 weeks of gestation presented with insomnia due to a compulsive urge to keep moving her legs. Blood tests revealed a Hb value of 10.1 g/dl. Which of the following is the most sensitive indicator for her underlying condition?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, history suggestive of restless leg syndrome and Hb of 10.1g/dL points to a diagnosis of iron deficiency anemia. Serum ferritin is the most sensitive indicator of iron deficiency anemia in pregnant women.

This is because its concentrations are not affected by the recent intake of iron-rich foods. Serum ferritin concentration <15 μg/L indicates iron deficiency anemia.

However, treatment needs to be initiated when the concentration falls <30 μg/L, as this indicates early iron depletion.

Restless leg syndrome also called Willis-Ekbom Disease, causes unpleasant or uncomfortable sensations in the legs along with an irresistible urge to move them. It may be associated with iron deficiency anemia.

questions.text:
Match the following delusions with associated syndrome:
Delusion Syndrome
i. Delusion of Love a. Capgras Syndrome
ii. Delusion of Misidentification b. De Clerambault syndrome
iii. Nihilistic Delusion c. Ekbom syndrome
iv. Delusion of infestation d. Cotard syndrome
  e. Othello syndrome
questions.solution:
Delusion and associated syndromes:

  • Delusion of love - De clerambault syndrome
  • Delusion of misidentification - Capgras syndrome
  • Nihilistic delusion - Cotard syndrome
  • Delusion of infestation - Ekbom syndrome

Delusion is a disorder of thought content and is defined as a false belief, based on incorrect inference about exter­nal reality, that is firmly held despite objective and obvious contradictory proof or evidence and despite the fact that other members of the culture do not share the belief.

Note: Restless legs syndrome is also called as Willis-Ekbom disease (RLS/WED). It is a chronic neurosensory disorder that is characterized by a strong urge to move, accompanied by uncomfortable paresthesia in the legs which affects about 5-15 percent of adult people in industrialized countries. Should not be confused with Ekbom syndrome.

 

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: When the pH  = pKa of a drug, which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Concentration of the drug is 50% ionic and 50 % non-ionic
Concentration of the drug is 90% ionic and 10% non-ionic
Concentration of the drug is 75% ionic and 25 % non-ionic
Concentration of the drug is 25% ionic and 75 % non-ionic

questions.solution:
When the pH = pKa of a drug, the concentration of the drug is 50% ionic and 50% non-ionic. 

pKa is defined as the pH at which a drug exists as 50% ionized (hydrophilic) and 50% unionized (lipophilic).

For e.g., phenobarbitone is an acidic drug with a pKa of 7.2. At a pH of 7.2, 50% will be unionized. In a more basic plasma (pH=7.4), a lesser fraction (around 40%) will be unionized.

Small changes in pH near pKa of a drug may cause large variations in the degree of ionization.

questions.text: An adolescent male patient presented with pain in the calf muscles on exercise. On biopsy, an excessive amount of glycogen was found to be present in the muscle. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are seen in McArdle's disease. This patient has muscle glycogen phosphorylase deficiency.

The lack of muscle glycogen phosphorylase results in excess glycogen build-up in muscles. The image given below shows the vacuolar myopathy seen in McArdle's disease.

Clinical features include poor exercise tolerance, abnormally high muscle glycogen (2.5-4%), and a very low blood lactate after exercise

The images given below show myophosphorylase enzyme histochemistry showing (A) Normal muscle and (B) McArdle's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following new drugs has been approved for the treatment of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Edaravone was approved by the FDA for the treatment of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

It has free radical scavenging properties that may reduce oxidative stress. The exact mechanism of action is unknown. It is to be administered as an IV infusion with an initial treatment cycle of daily dosing for 14 days, followed by a 14-day drug-free period. Subsequent treatment cycles consist of dosing on 10 of 14 days, followed by a 14 day drug-free period.

The major adverse effect of edaravone is hypersensitivity because the infusion contains sodium bisulfite. Other adverse effects include bruising, gait disorder, and headache.

Tafinlar (dabrafenib) and Mekinist (trametinib), are both indicated as monotherapy in BRAF V600E/K (BRAF V600E mutation-positive) melanoma. They are approved for combined administration, for the treatment of anaplastic thyroid cancer (ATC) that cannot be removed by surgery or that has spread to other parts of the body (metastatic).

Piracetam is a nootropic agent (a drug that enhances cognitive function) that is used off-label to enhance memory. It is also used to treat myoclonus.

questions.text: You are monitoring uterine contractions in a term primigravida in labor. You find that the contractions are uncoordinated and the frequency is about 8 contractions every 10 minutes. Which of the following is incorrect regarding your finding?

choices.text: It is common in nulliparous labour
Management includes wait and watch policy

questions.solution:
The given clinical finding is suggestive of uterine tachysystole. Oxytocin administration is not beneficial here as it leads to hyperstimulation of the uterus.

Tachysystole (hypertonic uterine dysfunction):

  • The uterine contractions are uncoordinated and increased in frequency (>5 contractions in 10 minutes)
  • Contractions occur with an increase in the baseline tone without rest in between them
  • It is associated with late active phase dysfunction i.e., when the cervix is almost 7 cm dilated
  • The most common cause is occipito-posterior position. Hence, a wait and watch policy is adopted
  • It is more common in nulliparous females
  • Oxytocin administration leads to hyperstimulation of the uterus and is not recommended.

Hypotonic uterine dysfunction:

  • Uterine contractions are inadequate
  • It is associated with early active phase
  • It is more common in nulliparous females.

questions.text: A young man presented with complaints of severe abdominal pain and watery diarrhoea eight hours after consuming meat at a restaurant.  A stool sample was sent for culture and the isolated organism showed this appearance on litmus milk fermentation. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the image showing stormy fermentation of lactose in litmus milk is suggestive of gastroenteritis caused by Clostridium perfingens type A.

The fermentation of lactose by this organism leads to the formation of acid which coagulates the casein in litmus milk. The clotted milk is disrupted due to vigorous gas production and this characteristic finding is obtained that is called stormy fermentation.

questions.text: On clinical examination, you find sensory loss in the region indicated. You would expect a deficit in:

choices.text: No associated motor weakness will be present

questions.solution:
The image shows Regimental Badge Sign. It is seen in Axillary nerve injuries. Axillary nerve supplies the deltoid which is responsible for abduction 15-90 degrees.

Other options:

  • Initiation of Abduction is not affected as it is caused by supraspinatus.
  • Overhead abduction is the function of serratus anterior and trapezius muscles and hence is not affected.
  • The posterior branch of axillary nerve supplies, teres minor and posterior of deltoid and terminates as the cutaneous nerve of armwhich supplies the skin over the lower half of deltoid. Deltoid muscle palsy can lead to loss of rounded contour of shoulder and palsy of lateral cutaneous nerve of arm are other significant features.

questions.text: A female constable of a police station accused the sub-inspector in charge of seducing her to have intercourse with her. He should be charged under I.P.C _________
questions.solution:
The sub inspector should be charged under IPC section 376 C since it is a case of rape by a person with authority.

The latest Supreme Court guidelines on rape:

  • Minimum Punishment for Rape has been increased from 7 years (earlier) to 10 years (updated). The maximum punishment remains the same, i.e. life imprisonment.
  • A new sub - section (3) has been added to Section 376, which prescribes the minimum punishment of 20 years for rape of a woman under 16 years of age.
  • A new Section 376AB has been inserted which prescribes the minimum punishment of 20 years rigorous imprisonment to a person committing rape on a woman less than 12 years of age.
  • New sections namely 376DA and 376DB prescribe minimum punishment of life imprisonment for persons involved in gang rape of woman aged less than 16 years and 12 years respectively.
  • Death penalty has been prescribed for gang rape on woman below 12 years of age.

Related Pearl: Sexual Offences

questions.text: A 32 year old male presented with a large volume of diarrhea, steatorrhea, and abdominal cramps. He gives a history of pneumonia  5 days back and was treated for it. On endoscopy following findings were seen, all are true regarding the condition except :

choices.text: Toxin B is responsible for large volume diarrhea and Toxin A result in abdominal cramps and bloody diarrhea
Diagnosed by Toxin A and B  in stools
Oral vancomycin is the drug of choice in mild to moderate disease
Oral fidaxomicin can be used for initial episode

questions.solution:
The endoscopic image shows pseudomembranous colitis caused by Clostridium difficile infection (CDI). It is most commonly associated with the use of antimicrobials like cephalosporin, ampicillin, fluoroquinolones, clindamycin etc.

Pathologically, the organism produces two toxins; Toxin A(Enterotoxin) causing large volume diarrhea and Toxin B(Cytotoxin) causing epithelial injury and bloody stools.

Diagnosis can be established by detection of toxins A & B in stools by PCR.

Oral Vancomycin is the drug of choice for CDI irrespective of the severity of the disease. However, oral fidaxomicin can be used as an alternative during the initial episode of CDI.

 

Related Pearl: Diagnostic criteria for Clostridium difficile infection

 

The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria:

1.Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause      

2.Detection of toxins A or B in the stool by PCR or culture

               or               

 Detection of pseudomembranes in the colon

questions.text: Which of the following features is not expected to be seen in a patient with a right middle cerebral artery infarct?
questions.solution:
Aphasia is not a feature of right middle cerebral artery infarct (MCA).

Aphasia occurs when there is damage to the dominant hemisphere, i.e., left hemisphere. The dominant hemisphere contains the language network which includes Broca’s area, Wernicke’s area, their interconnections and connections with frontal, parietal and temporal areas.

The MCA originates from the internal carotid artery. The stem of the MCA is referred to as the M1 segment. It gives rise to cortical and penetrating/lenticulostriate branches.

MCA stem occlusion leads to :

  • Contralateral hemiplegia
  • Hemianesthesia
  • Homonymous hemianopia
  • Global aphasia (dominant hemisphere)
  • Anosognosia, constructional apraxia, neglect (non-dominant hemisphere)

Occlusion of the lenticulostriate branches of MCA (lacunar stroke) may affect the genu of the internal capsule. This can lead to dysarthria with contralateral clumsy hand (fine motor weakness).

questions.text: The absence of which of the following milestones in a 3-year-old child is called as developmental delay?
questions.solution:
Feeding by spoon is a social milestone that typically appears by 18 months. If this is absent, then the child should be termed as having a developmental delay. Hopping on one leg, drawing a square, and passing a ball to someone appear by 48 months of age. 

Red flag signs in developmental screening and surveillance are indicators that suggest a serious disorder in a child's development, requiring referral to a pediatrician. These are given below: 

Positive indicators: Presence of any of the following

  • Loss of developmental skills at any age
  • Concerns about vision or confirmed visual impairment
  • Hearing loss at any age
  • Persistently low muscle tone
  • Lack of speech by 18 months without other means of communication
  • Asymmetry of movements or features suggestive of cerebral palsy
  • Persistent toe walking
  • Complex disabilities
  • Unusual head circumference compared to norms
  • Clinician uncertainty about the developmental disorder.

Negative Indicators:

  • Inability to sit unsupported by 12 months
  • Inability to walk by 18 months in boys or 2 years in girls.
  • Inability to walk normally
  • Inability to run by 2.5 years
  • Inability to hold objects in hand by 5 months or reach for them by 6 months.
  • Inability to point at objects to share interest by 2 years  

 

Related Pearl: Important developmental milestones at various ages

Developmental milestones 

At 1 year

  • Motor: Walks with support
  • Adaptive: Mature pincer grasp
  • Language: Speaks a few words
  • Social: Plays simple ball game
  • Domestic mimicry at 18 months

At 2 years

  • Motor: Walks up and downstairs, one step at a time
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 6 blocks 
  • Language: Simple sentences, a vocabulary of 50-100 words, uses pronouns at 2.5 yrs
  • Social: Asks for food and starts toilet training, listens to stories

At 3 years

  • Motor: Rides tricycle
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 9 blocks, handedness is established
  • Language: Knows full name, age, gender
  • Social: Plays simple games and engages in parallel play with other children

At 4 years

  • Motor: Hops
  • Adaptive: Draws square and constructs a bridge with blocks
  • Language: Tells stories
  • Social: Goes to the toilet alone
 At 5 years
  • Motor: Skips
  • Adaptive: Draws a triangle
  • Language: Asks the meaning of words, names 4 colors
  • Social: Dresses and undresses

questions.text: The membrane conductance for potassium is maximum at which of the following points in a nerve action potential?
questions.solution:
The membrane conductance for potassium is maximum during repolarization (marked as point 3 in the above image).   

Most of the increase in K+ conductance comes after the increase in Na+ conductance around the time of repolarization. 

During the early portion of the action potential, the sodium conductance is 1000 times greater than potassium conductance. Therefore, far more sodium ions flow to the interior of the fiber than do potassium ions to the exterior. This causes the membrane potential to become positive at the action potential onset.

When the membrane potential rises from −90 millivolts toward zero, this voltage change causes a conformational change in the K+ channels which allows increased potassium efflux. Then, the sodium channels begin to close and the potassium channels begin to open, and potassium conductance begins to increase (and sodium conductance decreases).

The increased flow of K+ out of the cell causes membrane repolarization. The slow return of the K+ channels to the closed state explains the after-hyperpolarization followed by a return to the resting membrane potential.

questions.text: Blood culture of the sputum sample taken from a patient diagnosed with hospital-acquired pneumonia, showed a characteristic phenomenon as shown in the image. Identify the bacteria that exhibit this phenomenon.
questions.solution:
The given image of the blood culture finding shows the characteristic bull's eye swarming pattern exhibited by Proteus.

Proteus species move very actively with the help of peritrichous flagella, resulting in swarming on solid media. It can be suppressed by the addition of:

  • phenyl ethyl alcohol
  • chloral hydrate
  • sulphonamides
  • sodium azide
  • boric acid
  • increasing the concentration of agar to 6%.

Swarming does not occur on MacConkey medium and cystine-lactose-electrolyte-deficient (CLED) medium.

Proteus is a gram-negative bacillus seen as a normal gastrointestinal flora. The two most common species causing infection in humans are P. mirabilis and P. vulgaris, which can be differentiated by spot indole test. P. mirabilis is indole negative while P. vulgaris is indole positive. Production of urease enzyme by Proteus, which hydrolyses urea to ammonia causes alkalinization of urine. Alkalinization of urine leads to the precipitation of organic and inorganic compounds which contributes to the formation of Struvite stones. P. mirabilis is associated with urinary tract infections while P. vulgaris is usually associated with wound and soft tissue infections. 

Other organisms that show swarming include:

  • Clostridium tetani
  • Vibrio parahaemolyticus
  • Serratia

questions.text: The center for vertical gaze is ________
questions.solution:
The Rostral Interstitial Nucleus of Cajal is the center for vertical gaze.

Vertical eye movement initiation in the frontal lobes is mediated by the impulses generated via the vertical gaze center called Rostral interstitial Nucleus of Cajal. This nucleus is a prominent group of cells present within the Medial Longitudinal Fasciculus (MLF) in the midbrain.

Pontine Paramedian Reticular Formation(Option A) is the center for horizontal gaze. Classically, initiation occurs in the premotor cortex frontal eye fields from where impulses for horizontal movement pass to the contralateral paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF).

Both horizontal and vertical gaze are saccadic types of conjugate eye movements. Conjugate eye movements, also known as versions, are binocular movements in which the eyes move synchronously in the same direction.

questions.text: During a health checkup in a factory, a 52-year-old worker complained of progressive cough and weight loss for the past 6 months. Chest X-ray showed a mass in the right apical region of the lung with pleural effusion. The biopsy sample obtained stained positive for calretinin. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: Immunohistochemical analysis will be positive for TTF-1.
Asbestos exposure is the major risk factor.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with biopsy showing positive calretinin is suggestive of mesothelioma. The immunohistochemical analysis will be negative for TTF-1 in mesothelioma. TTF-1 is positive in adenocarcinoma of the lung.

Malignant mesothelioma is the most common tumor of the pleura. Exposure to asbestos is the major known risk factor. The latency period between asbestos exposure and the development of mesothelioma is at least 20 years. It is more common in males, usually seen after 40 years of age. It has a very poor prognosis.

Histological subtypes include:

  • Epithelial
  • Sarcomatous
  • Biphasic

The physical characteristics of specific fibers are important for causation. They are:

  • Serpentine fibers: Large and curly, not able to travel beyond larger airways.
  • Amphibole fibers: The narrow, straight amphibole fibers, in particular, the crocidolite fibers navigate distally into the pulmonary parenchyma and are most clearly associated with mesotheliomas.

It is not bilaterally symmetrical. Its clinical features include:

  • Dyspnoea
  • Chest pain
  • Pleural effusion – in 90% cases

Diagnostic imaging includes chest X-ray, CT scan, and FDG-PET scan to determine the extent of tumor invasion and to evaluate occult metastases. Thoracoscopy or open pleural biopsy with special staining of tumor samples is required to differentiate mesotheliomas from adenocarcinomas.

Treatment includes a combination of surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy. Extrapleural pneumonectomy and total pleurectomy are two commonly used surgical procedures.

Related Pearl: Differentiation of Mesothelioma from Adenocarcinoma

questions.text: Which lymph nodes are considered always pathological when they are palpable?
questions.solution:
Palpable epitrochlear nodes are considered always pathological.

Head and neck lymphadenopathy is seen in 55% of patients, inguinal is seen in 14% of patients, and axillary lymphadenopathy is seen in 5% patients and the significance of these is varied.

questions.text: The arterial blood gas analysis of a patient reveals a pH of 7.55, pCO2- 54 mmHg, and HCO3- 40 mEq/L. What is the underlying disorder?

choices.text: Metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis
Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis
Respiratory alkalosis with compensatory metabolic acidosis

questions.solution:
The underlying disorder in this patient is metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: A pH of 7.55 indicates alkalosis.

Step 2: Plasma HCO3- is 40 mEq/L, which in the presence of a high pH indicates metabolic alkalosis.

Step 3: pCO2 is 54 mmHg indicating respiratory acidosis. The increase in pCO2 along with the increase in pH suggests that this is a compensatory response.

Step 4: Assessing the compensatory response:

On average, the pCO2 rises 0.75 mmHg for every 1.0 mEq/L increment in the plasma HCO3-

In the above scenario, the plasma HCO3- concentration is increased to 40 mEq/L (The average normal value is considered as 24 mEq/L)

Thus, the HCO3- elevation is 40 – 24 = 16 mEq/L

Therefore, pCO2 elevation should be 0.75 × 16 =  12 mmHg

Now, considering that the average value of normal pCO2 is 40 mmHg, the estimated pCO2 measured should be 40 + 12= 52 mmHg.

As pCO2 is higher than the expected estimate, it is a case of metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis.

HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg

questions.text: A patient with suspected tubal pregnancy underwent transvaginal ultrasound which was inconclusive. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the next step would be to confirm the tubal ectopic by measuring serum β hCG. This can be used to differentiate tubal ectopic pregnancy from missed abortion and early intrauterine pregnancy. 

If the level is ≥2000 IU/L, ectopic pregnancy is suspected. If the level is <1500 IU/L, a repeat serum β hCG is taken after 48 hours. If the levels are:

  • Doubled - early intrauterine pregnancy
  • Decreased - abortion
  • Increased but less than doubled value - ectopic pregnancy

Investigations for ectopic pregnancy:

  • Serum β hCG - lower levels compared to normal pregnancy, prolonged doubling time
  • Transvaginal ultrasound - empty uterine cavity, fluid in pouch of Douglas, adnexal mass
  • Colour Doppler - ring of fire pattern
  • Laparoscopy 
  • Dilatation and curettage - decidua identified without villi
  • Serum progesterone 
  • Culdocentesis 

Diagnostic laparoscopy may be done when the diagnosis is still uncertain after serial β-hCG monitoring and repeat ultrasonography. In high-risk situations, such as a history of previous ectopic pregnancy, earlier diagnostic laparoscopy is considered.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in the right order with respect to Vitamin D metabolism:
1) Cholecalciferol
2) 1, 25 dihydroxycholecalciferol 
3) 25 hydroxycholecalciferol 
4) 7 dehydrocholesterol
questions.solution:
7-dehydrocholesterol in the skin is converted to Cholecalciferol (Vit D3) by the action of sunlight.

Cholecalciferol is inactive and is converted to an active metabolite 25-hydroxycholecalciferol in the liver.

It is further converted to another active metabolite 1,25-hydroxycholecalciferol in the kidneys (proximal convoluted tubules).

questions.text: A primigravida presented with severe abdominal pain and fever at 28 weeks of gestation. Ultrasound reveals a healthy fetus in utero and a large submucosal fibroid with multiple, hyperechoic areas within. Blood investigations reveal leukocytosis and a raised ESR. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of red degeneration of fibroid. 

It is most common during the second trimester of pregnancy. The gross appearance is described as follows:

  • Fishy odor
  • Thrombosis of subcapsular vessels and vessels within the fibroid
  • Purplish-red color due to diffusion of blood pigments from the thrombosed vessels.

Red degeneration presents with acute abdominal pain, fever and, vomiting. Investigations reveal leukocytosis and a raised ESR. On radiology, the hemorrhagic areas appear hyperechoic within the fibroid.

The image given below shows the MRI appearance of red degeneration of fibroids

Option B: Torsion of subserous pedunculated fibroid presents with severe pain abdomen, but fever and leukocytosis are absent.

Option C: Infection is more common in puerperium and presents with blood-stained vaginal discharge.

Option D: Sarcomatous changes occur very rarely, and are unlikely in patients <40 years of age. They are more commonly seen in post-menopausal women.

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy
  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration
  • Red degeneration
  • Sarcomatous change
  • Torsion, hemorrhage
  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp
  • Inversion of the uterus
  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma
  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia
  • Accompanying adenomyosis
  • Parasitic fibroid

questions.text: Bone marrow aspirate of a patient shows the following features. Which of the following is true?

choices.text: Buffy coat is used to diagnose the parasite
It is an obligate extracellular parasite
Stibogluconate is the first line of treatment in India.

questions.solution:
The given image shows the amastigote form of leishmaniasis located intracellularly in macrophages. Buffy coat is used to diagnose the parasite.

Visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar) is a slowly progressing indigenous disease caused by a protozoan parasite of genus Leishmania. Leishmaniasis is a parasitic disorder transmitted by the bite of an infected female Phlebotomus sandfly in developing countries. The disease is transmitted by sand flies, which inoculate the flagellated promastigotes into the skin of the host.

In human beings, the disease presents in four different forms with a broad range of clinical manifestation:

  • Visceral leishmaniasis, or kala-azar,
  • Cutaneous leishmaniasis,
  • Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis, and
  • Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis.

The life cycle of Leishmania involves two forms,

  • The promastigote which develops and lives extracellularly in the sandfly vector and
  • The amastigote which multiplies intracellularly in the reticuloendothelial cells of the host.

It lowers immunity, causes persistent fever, anemia, liver and spleen enlargement, and if left untreated, death may occur due to opportunistic infection.

Diagnosis:

  • Rapid diagnostic test: rK39 Rapid diagnostic test and Kala azar dipstick test strip.
  • Parasitological diagnosis: Demonstration of LD bodies in buffy coat smear - confirmatory.
  • Aldehyde test of Napier: Widely used for surveillance.
  • Serological tests for diagnosis: Rapid dipstick test, Direct agglutination test, ELISA, Indirect Fluorescent Antibody Test
  • Leishmanin (Montenegro) test: Induration of 5mm or more is considered positive, usually positive 4-6 weeks after onset in cutaneous leishmaniasis, valuable for distinguishing immune from nonimmune subjects and endemicity.

Drugs used in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis are sodium stibogluconate, miltefosine, and amphotericin. Liposomal amphotericin single dose 10mg/Kg IV is the first line of treatment in India.

questions.text: Aztreonam has activity against ____.
questions.solution:
Aztreonam has activity only against gram-negative bacteria. It has no activity against gram-positive bacteria and anaerobes. 

Clinical correaltion 

Aztreonam is therefore useful in treating gram-negative infections that normally would be treated with a beta lactam antibiotic but cannot be done because of the previous penicillin allergy.

Remember: Aztreonam has lacks allergic cross-reactivity with beta lactam antibiotics except with ceftazidime as it shares an exact side chain with it.

questions.text: A young male who is shy and prefers social isolation appears to be emotionally cold and resides alone. There is no history of hallucinations or delusions. The most likely diagnosis is __________
questions.solution:
The diagnosis, in this case, is schizoid personality disorder.

Schizoid personality disorder is a cluster A personality disorder. The patient neither desires nor enjoys close relationships (shy and prefers social isolation, resides alone as in the question) and shows emotional coldness and detachment.

In contrast, subjects with emotionally unstable (borderline) personality disorder cannot tolerate being alone, and they search for companionship.

Related Pearl: Personality Disorders

questions.text: A 60-year-old male who is on warfarin prophylaxis for atrial fibrillation presents with massive uncontrolled haemorrhage following a fall from height. Which of the following blood components can be used for emergency reversal of warfarin therapy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Prothrombin Complex Concentrates (PCCs) are indicated for the emergency reversal of anticoagulant (warfarin) therapy in uncontrolled hemorrhage.

PCCs are highly purified concentrates prepared from pooled plasma. They contain factors II, IX and X. Factor VII may be included or produced separately.

Fresh frozen plasma and platelets are used in management of coagulopathy. Fresh frozen plasma is used if prothrombin time (PT) or partial thromboplastin time (PTT) >1.5 times normal. Platelets are transfused if platelet count <50 x103/ul.

However, in the presence of non-surgical haemorrhage these tests take time to arrange and may underestimate the degree of coagulopathy.

questions.text: Cytotoxic and expired drugs are disposed by:
questions.solution:
Cytotoxic and expired drugs are disposed along with their packaging in a yellow bag by incineration.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with medullary thyroid carcinoma. Which of the following could be used to screen the rest of her family?
questions.solution:
Screening of patients with familial MTC was historically done using pentagastrin stimulation test for calcitonin levels to make the diagnosis. 

Pentagastrin is a synthetic gastrin analogue. It acts on the CCK-B/gastrin receptor of the C cells and increases the basal rate of calcitonin secretion.

Basal calcitonin level = total C cell mass x rate of secretion.

Medullary thyroid tumors secrete calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), but also other peptides such as calcitonin gene-related peptide, histaminadases, prostaglandins E2 and F2α, and serotonin.

Another test that can be used for screening is calcium-stimulated calcitonin levels.

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text: A woman presents with fever with chills and a productive cough. Chest X-ray is suggestive of lobar pneumonia. She had undergone splenectomy 2 years back. Sputum culture on blood agar shows the following. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of bacterial pneumonia in a splenectomised individual along with the image showing satellitism on blood agar points towards an infection due to Hemophilus influenzae.

Pneumonia can occur as a part of overwhelming post-splenectomy infection (OPSI). This is a fatal post-splenectomy complication occuring due to infections with encapsulated organisms such as S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae, and N. meningitidis. It can be prevented by vaccinating against these organisms within 2 weeks of undergoing splenectomy. 

Satellitism is seen when S. aureus is streaked across a plate of blood agar on which H. influenzae has been inoculated. After overnight incubation, the colonies of H. influenzae will be large and well developed alongside the streak of Staphylococcus and smaller when they are farther away from the streak. This is due to the release of factor V by lysis of RBCs mediated by S. aureus. Factor V is required for the growth of H. influenzae.

The given image shows satellitism on blood agar

questions.text: Which of the following parameters is used to assess the extent of drug absorption in a plasma concentration vs. time graph?
questions.solution:
The area under the curve of plasma concentration vs. time curve gives the extent of absorption, which is calculated by the trapezoidal rule. 

The following image shows a plasma concentration vs. time graph:

Two drugs may have the same rate of absorption but a different extent of absorption or bioavailability. 

The factors upon which the extent of drug absorption depends are:

  • Lipophilicity - If too lipophilic (e.g., acyclovir), the drug is not soluble enough to cross the water layer adjacent to the cell.
  • Hydrophilicity - If too hydrophilic (e.g., atenolol), the drug cannot cross the lipid cell membrane.

questions.text: A person is brought to the emergency department following a blast. On investigation, a small metallic foreign body is found entrapped in the lens of his right eye. What is the best treatment option?
questions.solution:
For a patient with a foreign body in the lens, the best treatment option is complete removal of the lens.

If a foreign body lies within the lens, it is better to treat such particles as if they were non-magnetic or to remove the lens as a whole. For a non-magnetic foreign body:-

  • The foreign body on iris it can usually be picked out by an iris forceps through a suitably placed keratome incision. If entangled an iridectomy is performed.
  • If the foreign body is in the lens, a few days should be allowed to elapse for the aqueous to act upon the lens fibers. Aspiration is then performed and the foreign body is removed with the lens matter.
  • If the foreign body lies on the retina, and if accurate localization has been attained, it is removed directly by intra-vitreal forceps as part of a complete vitrectomy. Laser photocoagulation of the surrounding retina is also done to prevent a late retinal detachment.

questions.text: What is the adjuvant therapy in fungal corneal ulcer?
questions.solution:
Atropine sulfate (1%) eye ointment or eye drops is used as the nonspecific supportive treatment in both bacterial as well as a fungal corneal ulcer.

Atropine sulphate (1%) is a cycloplegic drug that is used as an adjunct in the treatment of corneal ulcers to

  • reduce pain from ciliary spasm
  • Prevent posterior synechiae formation that can develop from secondary iridocyclitis
  • Increase blood supply to the anterior chamber that gets more antibodies into aqueous humor
  • Reduce exudation by decreasing hyperpermeability of the vessels

Another cycloplegic that can be used as an adjunct is homatropine 2%.

Topical steroids such as Dexamethasone(option C) will increase fungal replication and corneal invasion and hence are contraindicated in the treatment of fungal corneal ulcers.

Management of fungal corneal ulcer includes

Definitive treatment:

  • Topical antifungal eye drops: used for 6-8 weeks 
  • Filamentous fungi such as Aspergillus and Fusarium- Drug of choice (DOC) is natamycin (5%). Others include amphotericin B (0.1-0.3%), fluconazole (0.2%) or voriconazole 10%.
  • Yeast such as Candida- Drug of choice (DOC) is Amphotericin B. Others include Nystatin 3.5%. 
  • Intracameral or intracorneal administration of Voriconazole in cases with intraocular extension or anterior chamber involvement.
  • Systemic antifungals such as tablet fluconazole are given in severe cases of deeper fungal keratitis.
  • Therapeutic penetrating keratoplasty for unresponsive cases.

Adjunct therapy:

  1. Cycloplegics : Atropine sulphate 1% or homatropine 2%
  2. Systemic analgesics and anti-inflammatory drugs such as paracetamol, ibuprofen to decrease pain and edema.
  3. Vitamins A,B-complex,C- to aid healing of the ulcer.
  4. Hot fomentation, dark goggles, rest, good diet.

questions.text: Cryoprecipitate is useful for the management of patients with all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
Cryoprecipitate does not contain factor IX. Hence, it is not useful for the management of patients with Christmas disease, which occurs due to deficiency of factor IX.

Components of cryoprecipitate are:

  • Factor VIII
  • Factor XIII
  • Fibrinogen
  • Fibronectin
  • Von Willebrand factor

Therefore it can be used in patients with hemophilia A, factor XIII deficiency, hypofibrinogenemia, and von Willebrand disease.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman complains of urine dribbling from the vagina. On further examination and investigation, she is diagnosed with a vesicovaginal fistula. Which of the following is false about the management of her condition?

choices.text: Latzko procedure is suited for post-hysterectomy fistula, caused by cancer cervix
Following a failed attempt, a second attempt can be made after 4 weeks
Continous bladder drainage required for 14 days postoperatively
Sexual abstinence for 3 months is advised after the surgery

questions.solution:
In case the fistula repair fails, a second attempt is made only after 3 months.

Vesicovaginal fistula(VVF) is a type of genital fistula, which is an abnormal communication between the genital tract and the urinary tract. It occurs mostly due to obstetric injuries such as prolonged labor, and instrumental or manipulative deliveries. Patients present with true incontinence characterized by constant dribbling of urine.

Small fistulas due to difficult childbirth can heal spontaneously. In the case of an established fistula, it is better to wait for about 3 months for all tissue inflammation to subside, before surgery is undertaken. Most vesicovaginal fistulas are repaired per vaginally. The various surgeries done for the repair of VVF are as follows:

  • Latzko procedure: It is done by denudation of vaginal epithelium around fistulous edges and approximation of raw surface with absorbable sutures. This technique is suited for post-hysterectomy fistula that is caused by cancer cervix (Option A). It can lead to narrowing of the vagina or vaginal atresia. Fistula located at the vaginal vault, post hysterectomy is the most difficult to treat, this technique is suited for such cases.
  • Chassar-Moir technique: Here, the vagina and bladder are separated and sutured into two layers taking care to avoid tension and overlapping suture lines. 
  • Ureteric implantation into the sigmoid colon in case previous surgeries fail.

Post-operatively, continuous bladder drainage for 14 days (Option C) along with antibiotics is recommended. Vaginal or speculum examination and intercourse are not advised for 3 months after surgery (Option D). Avoiding pregnancy for a year is also recommended. A cesarean section is usually done for future pregnancies.

Related Pearl: Difference between bladder fistula & ureteric fistula

  Bladder fistula   Ureteric fistula 
Etiology

Obstetric causes:

  • Prolonged obstructed labor
  • Instrumental deliveries
  • Iatrogenic injury during caesarean section or sling operations

Surgical injury during:

  • Abdominal hysterectomy
  • Vaginal hysterectomy
  • Wertheim's hysterectomy
  • Laparoscopic surgeries
  • Caesarean section
Clinical features

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is unable to micturate

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is able to micturate
Methylene blue 3-swab test Middle swab stains with methylene blue   Uppermost swab stains with urine, but not with methylene blue
Intravenous pyelography Normal Hydronephrosis and hydroureter present on the affected side

 

Related Pearl: Methylene blue - 3 swab test

In the methylene blue 3-swab test, a catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra. The vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile cotton swabs. One at the vault, one at the middle, and one just above the introitus. A diluted solution of methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder using a transurethral catheter. After 15 to 30 minutes, the swabs are removed serially and inspected for dye.

Interpretation:

  • Upper swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter: Ureterovaginal fistula
  • Middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder: Vesicovaginal fistula
  • Lower swab gets stained - the leak is from the urethra: Urethrovaginal fistula

The given image shows the 3-swab test.

questions.text: An elderly woman presents with a sudden increase in the lesions given in the image. Which of the following should be suspected?
questions.solution:
This image shows seborrheic keratosis. A sudden appearance of multiple seborrheic keratoses in association with skin tags and acanthosis nigricans has been associated with a variety of malignancies, including gastrointestinal and lung cancers; it is also known as the Leser-Trélat sign.

Seborrheic keratoses are common epidermal tumors consisting of a benign proliferation of immature keratinocytes. They present as well-demarcated, round or oval lesions with a dull, verrucous surface and a typical stuck-on appearance.

questions.text: The following graph displays which physiological law of the heart?
questions.solution:
The diagram displays the Length-Tension relationship for a cardiac muscle explaining the Starling law of the heart.

In the body, the initial length of the fibers is determined by the degree of diastolic filling of the heart, and the pressure developed in the ventricle is proportional to the volume of the ventricle at the end of the filling phase (Starling law of the heart).

  • The developed tension increases as the diastolic volume increases until it reaches a maximum, then tends to decrease.
  • The decrease is due to beginning disruption of the myocardial fibers and not due to a decrease in the number of cross-bridges between actin and myosin as seen in skeletal muscle.

questions.text: Which of the following agents is used in the treatment of patients who develop severe thrombocytopenia following anti-cancer therapy?
questions.solution:
Oprelvekin is used in the treatment of thrombocytopenia secondary to anti-cancer therapy.

It is a recombinant human interleukin-11. Its predominant hemopoietic activity is the stimulation of megakaryocytopoiesis. Oprelvekin is indicated for the prevention and treatment of severe thrombocytopenia and the reduction of platelet transfusion requirements following myelosuppressive chemotherapy in patients with non-myeloid malignancies.

questions.text: A 14 year old girl presents to the emergency room with fracture forearm and says she has tripped and fell. On examination you notice multiple cigarette burns on her forearm. What will you do next?
questions.solution:
A child who has been physically abused should undergo a thorough physical examination at first.

This should be followed by a psychiatric interview.

When the child is brought to the emergency room, a detailed and spontaneous account of the injury should be obtained promptly from parents or other caregivers before secondary details and rationalizations cloud the information provided.

questions.text: Among the following, what is the most common symptom of adult obsessive-compulsive disorder?
questions.solution:
Among the above options, pathological doubt is the common symptom of adult OCD. Pathological doubt is the second most common pattern of adult obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), only after obsession of contamination.

Pathological doubt is an obsession with doubt, followed by a compulsion to check. The obses­sion often implies some danger of violence e.g., forgetting to turn off the stove or not locking a door. The checking may involve multiple trips back into the house to check the stove. These patients have obsessional self-doubt and always feel guilty about having forgotten or committed something.

The frequency of presenting patterns of OCD :

Obsession of contamination > Pathological doubt > Intrusive thoughts> Symmetry

questions.text: Which of the following structures marked in the below image gives rise to the heart in an adult?
questions.solution: The structure marked ‘C’ in the above image depicts the heart bulge.

questions.text: A baby assessed at 5 minutes after birth, had blue extremities and irregular gasping respiration. Heart rate was 40/min and there was  grimace with some flexion of extremities. APGAR score for this newborn is _______
questions.solution:
APGAR score in this baby is 5.

In this baby

  • Colour: Blue extremities - score 1
  • HR < 100/min - score 1
  • Grimace - score 1
  • Some flexion of extremities - score 1
  • Irregular respiration - score 1

Thus total score is 5.

At 1 minute and 5 minutes after birth of the infant, the 5 objective signs listed here are evaluated and each is given a score of 0, 1, or 2.

A total score of 10 indicates an infant in the best possible condition. An infant with a score of 0-3 requires immediate resuscitation.

Related Pearl: APGAR score

questions.text: The O2-CO2 diagram shown below shows a ventilation-perfusion ratio curve for the normal lung. Which of the following options best describes the effect of decreasing the ventilation-perfusion ratio on the alveolar Po2 and Pco2?
questions.solution:
Decreased ventilation-perfusion ratio implies decreased oxygenation due to decreased ventilation with respect to perfusion. Hence, PAO2 decreases and Pco2 increases.

A decrease in the ventilation-perfusion ratio (VA/Q) is depicted by moving to the left along the normal ventilation-perfusion line as shown in the figure (Zones here refer to the zones of variation in pulmonary blood flow and alveolar ventilation under influence of gravity)

  • Zone 1 - Zone 1 has the lowest ventilation compared to Zones 2 and 3 but, in Zone 1 Ventilation (V)>>Perfusion (Q) hence V­/Q­ is high
    • PAO2 is highest
    • PACO2 is lowest
  • Zone 2 -  Ventilation (V) almost equal to Perfusion (Q) but slightly lower so V/Q is average (~0.8)
  • Zone 3 - Zone 3 has the highest ventilation compared to Zones 2 and 1 but, in Zone 3 Perfusion (Q) >> Ventilation (V) hence V­/Q­ is low 
    • PAO2 is lowest
    • PACO2 is highest.

*PAO2 - Alveolar partial pressure of oxygen

*PACO2 - Alveolar partial pressure of CO2

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis based on the given image?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts restricted lateral movement of the left eye when the person is in left lateral gaze. This is suggestive of left lateral rectus muscle paralysis due to isolated 6th cranial nerve palsy.

Isolated abducens(6th cranial) nerve palsy presents with esotropia / convergent squint in primary position with limitation of abduction on the side of the lesion.
This is due to unopposed action of the medial rectus muscle in the affected eye. There is also a compensatory head turn towards the side of the lesion to reduce the symptom of diplopia. The adduction is normal in 6th nerve palsy.

 The various causes of 6th nerve palsy includes:

  • Raised intracranial pressure
  • Nasopharyngeal tumors
  • Gradenigo syndrome as seen in mastoiditis or acute petrositis
  • Basal skull fracture

 

Option A: 3rd Cranial nerve palsy presents with

  • ptosis due to weakness of levator palpebrae superioris muscle(LPS)
  • Abduction and depression in the primary position(down and out) due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus(6th nerve supply) and superior oblique muscles(4th nerve supply)
  • Dilated pupil and defective accommodation due to parasympathetic palsy(involvement of Edinger Westphal parasympathetic supply)
  • Limited adduction, elevation due to ipsilateral paralysis of medial rectus, inferior oblique and inferior rectus .

 

Option D: Bell’s palsy is an acute onset, idiopathic lower motor neuron lesion of the facial nerve which involves the ipsilateral upper and lower halves of the face.
It presents with an inability to close the eye and any attempts to close the eye results in the eye turning upwards and outwards which is known as the Bell’s phenomenon. Other features of Bell's palsy include drooling of saliva, deviation of angle of the mouth and facial asymmetry. Additionally there may be noise intolerance and a loss of taste sensation.
The following image shows a patient with Bell’s palsy:

 

Option D: Horner syndrome, also called oculosympathetic paresis, is produced by a lesion anywhere along the sympathetic pathway supplying the head, neck and eyes. It is characterized by the classical triad of ptosis, miosis and anhidrosis(reduced ipsilateral sweating). Other features include mild enophthalmos, hypochromic heterochromia and anisocoria that is accentuated in dim light.

Tests for confirmation of Horner's syndrome -

  • Cocaine drops (2-4%)
    Horner pupil does not dilate
    Normal pupil dilates
  • Apraclonidine drops (0.5-1%)
    Horner pupil dilates - due to upregulation of α1 receptors in the dilator pupillae.
    Normal pupil does not dilate

questions.text: Which one of the following statements is true regarding pathogenicity of Mycobacteria species?

choices.text: M. tuberculosis is more pathogenic than M. bovis to the humans
M. kansasii can cause a disease indistinguishable from tuberculosis
M. africanum infection is acquired from the environmental source
M. marinum is responsible for tubercular lymphadenopathy

questions.solution:
Mycobacterium kansasii can cause a clinical syndrome that strongly resembles tuberculosis, consisting of hemoptysis, chest pain, and cavitary lung disease. M. kansasii is the most pathogenic non-tuberculous mycobacterial species affecting the lung.

Option A: M. tuberculosis is equally pathogenic as M. bovis to humans and guinea pigs. However, M. bovis but not M. tuberculosis is pathogenic to rabbits.

Option C: M. africanum is a member of the Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex. It is is spread by an airborne route from affected individuals and not from an environmental source. 

Option D: M. marinum causes swimming pool granuloma/fish tank granuloma/fish fancier’s finger. M. scrofulaceum causes chronic lymphadenitis.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is not a cell mediated type of hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
Casoni’s test is a type I hypersensitivity reaction used in the diagnosis of hydatid disease.

  • It involves the intradermal injection of 0.25 ml of sterilized fluid from hydatid cysts/human cyst and sterilized by Seitz filtration on the forearm and an equal volume of saline injected on the other forearm.
  • Observations are made for next 30 mins and after 1 to 2 days.
  • A wheal response occurring at the injection site within 20 minutes is considered positive.

Cell-mediated or type IV type of hypersensitivity reaction is a delayed hypersensitivity. 

In the tuberculin skin test, the indurated skin rash is caused by CD4-positive helper T cells and macrophages that are attracted to the injection site.

The Frei test is done to identify lymphogranuloma venereum. Antigen made from sterile pus aspirated from previously unruptured abscesses produced a reaction in patients with lymphogranuloma inguinale when injected intradermally.

Montenegro test is a delayed hypersensitivity test for cutaneous leishmaniasis.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman who presented with aquagenic pruritis had a Hb level of 20 g/dL. Her lab investigations are given below. Which of the following is not seen in this condition?

Hb - 19 g/dL

Hematocrit - 52%

S. erythropoietin - decreased

JAK2 mutation - positive
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polycythemia vera. Hepatic failure is not seen in this condition.

Polycythemia vera is strongly associated with activating point mutations in the tyrosine kinase JAK2. In this condition, clonal erythrocytosis occurs autonomously i.e. independent of erythropoietin.

Clinical features of polycythemia vera:

  • Headache
  • Hypertension
  • Dizziness
  • Intense pruritis, aquagenic pruritis
  • Peptic ulcer
  • Venous thrombosis - Budd-Chiari syndrome (hepatic vein thrombosis), bowel infarction, stroke, myocardial infarction
  • Minor hemorrhages - epistaxis, gum bleeding

Laboratory findings in polycythemia vera:

  • Panmyelosis - increased marrow production of red cells, granulocytes, and platelets
  • Low erythropoietin
  • Elevated hematocrit
  • Hyperuricemia

Complications of polycythemia vera:

  • Myelofibrosis and extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis - spent /late phase
  • Acute myeloid leukemia

The FDA has recently approved Ropeginterferon alfa-2b injection to treat adults with polycythemia vera. It is the first interferon therapy specifically approved for polycythemia vera. Ropeginterferon alfa-2b is a long-acting drug that patients take by injection under the skin once every two weeks.

Related Pearl: WHO Polycythemia Vera Criteria

Major criteria:

1. Hemoglobin >16.5 g/dL in men

     Hemoglobin >16.0 g/dL in women 

Or

     Hematocrit >49% in men

     Hematocrit >48% in women 

2. Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage hyperplasia (panmyelosis) and prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation with pleomorphic mature megakaryocytes in the bone marrow, and 

3. Presence of JAK2 exon 12 mutation

Minor criterion:

Subnormal serum erythropoietin level

Diagnosis of polycythemia vera requires meeting either all 3 major criteria or the first 2 major criteria along with the minor criterion

questions.text: What is the most common cause of agranulocytosis?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of agranulocytosis is drug toxicity.

Causes of agranulocytosis include:

  • Inadequate or ineffective granulopoiesis -
    • Suppression of hematopoietic stem cells - aplastic anemia, infiltrative marrow disorders
    • Suppression of committed granulocytic precursors
    • Ineffective hematopoiesis - megaloblastic anemia, myelodysplastic syndromes
    • Congenital conditions - Kostmann syndrome
  • Increased destruction or sequestration of neutrophils -
    • Immunological injury to neutrophils - idiopathic, systemic lupus erythematosus, drug exposure
    • Increased peripheral utilization - bacterial, fungal, or rickettsial infections
    • Splenomegaly

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding clavicular shaft fracture?

choices.text: The most commonly fractured bone is clavicle
Non-union is the most common complication
Displaced fractures are treated with intramedullary nails

questions.solution:
Non-union is a relatively rare complication in clavicle shaft fracture. Malunion is the most common complication in clavicle fractures

The most common bone to be fractured is the clavicle. It is also the most common bone to be fractured during birth. Neurological deficit is rare in clavicular shaft fractures. 

Undisplaced fractures are treated with a sling or figure of eight bandages for 2-3 weeks. This is followed by mobilization of the limb as the pain subsides. 

Displaced fractures are treated with internal fixation either by contoured locking plates or intramedullary nails.

questions.text: A man inspires 1000ml from a spirometer. The intrapleural pressure was -4cm H2O before inspiration and -12cm H20 at the end of inspiration. What is the compliance of lungs?(ml/cm H20)?
questions.solution:
Compliance is change in volume per unit change in pressure.

  • C= ΔV/ΔP

In this case,

ΔV= 1000 mL

ΔP= -12-(-4) = -8 cm of H2O

The minus sign indicates that the pressure has fallen by 8cms of H20 at the end of inspiration

Therefore the compliance is,

C= 1000/8= 125 mL/cm of H2O

questions.solution:
Nevirapine is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI)

US FDA has approved doravirine, a new non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor(NNRTI) for the treatment of adults with HIV-1 infection given in combination with other ARTs.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man on routine dental checkup was found to have the following finding on orthopantomogram. What is the reason for the finding marked with the arrow?
questions.solution:
The given orthopantomogram shows a right-sided clearly demarcated radiolucent lesion suggestive of a stafne bone cyst. It is the most common type of ectopic salivary tissue.

It presents as an asymptomatic, clearly demarcated radiolucent lesion at the angle of the mandible, characteristically below the inferior dental neurovascular bundle. It is more common in males. Usually, no treatment is required.

A dentigerous cyst is a cyst in relation to an unerupted tooth. Most commonly involves the 3rd molar. It is managed by enucleation and removal of the tooth.

questions.text: A patient with Crohn's disease has multiple skip lesions in the intestine. Surgical resection of damaged areas is being planned. Removal of which part will cause steatorrhoea?
questions.solution:
Ileal resection may lead to steatorrhoea.

The ileum is the only site of absorption of vitamin B12 and bile salts. Following resection of the ileum, the loss of bile salts increases and is not met by an increase in synthesis. Depletion of the bile salt pool results in fat malabsorption that presents with steatorrhea.

The efficiency of water absorption in the jejunum is 44% and in the is ileum 70%. Resection of ileum causes reduced conservation of fluid. Loss of bile salts into the colon affects colonic mucosa, causing a reduction in salt and water absorption, which increases stool losses. 

Small bowel motility is three times slower in the ileum than in the jejunum. In addition, the ileocaecal valve may slow the transit. Resection of the ileum results in a significant enhancement of gastric motility and acceleration of intestinal transit.

questions.text: Identify the anomaly
questions.solution:
The given picture is of craniorachischisis which is the most severe form of dysraphism. It occurs due to total failure of neural tube closure.

Cranio indicates cranium, rachi indicates spine, schisis indicates split. The brain and spinal chord are exposed to the surrounding amniotic fluid, resulting in necrosis, degeneration or angioma-like formations.

Alpha fetoprotein (AFP) is found in amniotic fluid and maternal serum, and is an indicator of neural tube defects.

Neural tube defect prophylaxis byFolic Acid: 400 mcg (WHO) and 500 mcg (MoHFW- India).

Spina bifida is a developmental anomaly characterized by defective closure of vertebral arch associated with maternal folic acid deficiency and is classified into various types.

Several forms is Spina bifida occulta.

- Failure of vertebrae to close around spinal cord (tufts of hair often evident),

- No increase in AFP

  • Spinal meningocele (spina bifida cystica)

- Meninges extend out of defective spinal canal

- raised AFP

  • Meningomyelocele

- Meninges and spinal cord extend out of spinal canal

- Raised AFP

  • Myeloschisis (most severe form)

- Neural tissue is visible externally

- Raised AFP

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: Most drugs are absorbed in the ionized form.
Basic drugs are generally bound to plasma albumin.
Microsomal enzymes are located in the mitochondria of hepatic cells.
Blood brain barrier is deficient at the chemoreceptor trigger zone.

questions.solution:
The blood-brain barrier is deficient at the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ) in the medulla oblongata. Lipid insoluble drugs can act as emetics or anti-emetics through its action on CTZ.

Option A: Ionized forms of drugs are lipid insoluble and are not absorbed. It is the lipid-soluble non-ionized forms that are absorbed.

Option B: Plasma protein binding:

  • Basic drugs - alpha 1 acid glycoprotein
  • Acidic drugs - albumin

Option C: Metabolizing enzymes in hepatic cells:

  • Microsomal enzymes - smooth endoplasmic reticulum
  • Non-microsomal enzymes - mitochondria and cytoplasm

questions.text: A woman presents with bluish discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes. All of the following may be responsible for the given symptoms except:
questions.solution:
Bluish discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes is suggestive of cyanosis. Cyanosis is seen when the concentration of deoxygenated or reduced hemoglobin exceeds 4 gm/dL.

Cyanosis is detectable with methemoglobin ≥1.5 gm% and/or sulfhemoglobin ≥0.5 gm%.

Central cyanosis is detectable when the oxygen saturation <85%. In dark-skinned individuals, it may be detectable at an oxygen saturation of 75%.

The types of cyanosis are:

Central cyanosis Peripheral cyanosis

Due to diminished arterial oxygen saturation/presence of abnormal hemoglobin derivative.

Due to diminished peripheral blood flow.

Mucous membranes and skin are both affected

 Mucous membranes of the oral cavity or those beneath the tongue are spared.

Decreases after O2 supplementation

 Does not decrease after O2 supplementation

questions.text: An obstetrician is performing a breech delivery. Which of the following manoeuvres can be used for chin to pubis delivery?
questions.solution:
In a breech presentation, chin to pubis delivery can be done by Prague manoeuvre.

Rarely, the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the anterior. In such cases, rotation of the posteriorly oriented back of the fetus to the anterior may be achieved by using stronger traction on the fetal legs or bony pelvis.

If this still does not succeed, the fetus still may be delivered using the modified Prague manoeuvre. This consists of two fingers of one hand grasping the shoulders of the back-down fetus from below while the other hand draws the feet up and over the maternal abdomen.

If the back is oriented anteriorly, extraction may be accomplished using the Mauriceau manoeuvre and delivering the fetus back down.

  • If the fetal back is anterior - Mauriceau manoeuvre.
  • If the fetal back is posterior - Modified Prague manoeuvre. (Mnemonic: P for P)

questions.text: Which one of the following is not involved in iron metabolism:
questions.solution:
• Hepcidin, ceruloplasmin, and transferrin are involved in iron metabolism.
  • Transthyretin transports thyroxine and retinol-binding protein and has no role in iron metabolism

Proteins involved in iron metabolism:

  • Ferritin and hemosiderin: Iron storage
  • Transferrin: Iron transport
  • Ceruloplasmin: a copper-containing enzyme with ferroxidase activity
  • Hepcidin: Chief regulator of systemic iron homeostasis

questions.text: When the membrane potential decreases from +35 mV to -40 mV, the voltage-gated sodium channels are most likely to be in which state?
questions.solution:
When the membrane potential is decreasing towards the resting potential (becomes more negative), the Na+ channels are most likely to be in their inactivated state (C in the given image).

Voltage-Gated Sodium Channels have two gates— an activation gate near the outside of the channel and an inactivation gate near the inside.

Resting-State (Image A): The membrane potential is initially -70 mv and the activation gate is closed at this stage. This prevents any entry of sodium ions to the interior of the fiber through these sodium channels.

  • Activated State (Image B): When the membrane potential rises from -70 millivolts toward zero, it causes a sudden conformational change in the activation gate, flipping it to the open position. During this activated state, sodium ions can move inward through the channel. 
  • Inactivated State (Image C): The rise in membrane potential toward zero also produces a conformational change that flips the inactivation gate to the closed state. But this is a slower process compared to the opening of the activation gate. Therefore, the inactivation gate closes a few 10,000ths of a second after the sodium channel has opened and sodium ions can no longer move inside. Following this, the membrane potential begins to return toward the resting membrane state, which is the repolarization process.

The inactivation gate will not reopen until the membrane potential returns to or near the original resting membrane potential level. Therefore, the sodium channels can only open after the nerve fiber is repolarized.

questions.text: A young man presented with complaints of a tingling sensation in his hands and feet. He also complains of weakness in his legs that is slowly spreading to his upper body. He had an episode of bloody diarrhea 10 days ago.  Which of the following organisms is the likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario with ascending paralysis is suggestive of the development Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) following diarrhea. The organism that likely caused this patients condition is Campylobacter jejuni, which can cause diarrhea and trigger GBS. 

Campylobacter is a slender, spirally curved, gram-negative bacillus. Growth occurs under microaerophilic conditions. The organism also shows darting motility. Asymptomatic campylobacter infection also may trigger Guillain-Barré syndrome.

Guillain-Barre syndrome is an acute, fulminant polyradiculoneuropathy that is autoimmune in nature. In C. jejuni infection, bacterial lipopolysaccharide triggers an autoimmune response against axons via molecular mimicry, hence causing GBS. Other organisms associated with GBS include cytomegalovirus, M. pneumonia, and Epstein-Barr virus.

questions.text: An anaesthetist notices that the soda lime is exhausted and requests for it to be changed. If the indicator used is ethyl violet, what would be the color change observed?
questions.solution:
When carbon dioxide absorbing capacity of soda lime using ethyl violet indicator is exhausted, the color changes from white to purple.
