questions.text:
Real time polymerase chain reaction is done for ___________
1.	DNA detection
2.	RNA detection
3.	Monitoring amplification of target nucleic acid
questions.solution: The PCR (Polymerase chain reaction) is a method of amplifying a target sequence of DNA. PCR provides a sensitive, selective, and extremely rapid means of amplifying any desired sequence of DNA. Real time PCR is a method by which the amount of the PCR product can be determined, and is very useful for investigating gene expression. It uses fluorescent dyes or specific DNA probes. It is also known as qPCR (Quantitative PCR).

questions.text: An airline ground staff officer with difficulty hearing is found to have permanent hearing loss on follow up. Continuous exposure to sound above what intensity can cause this condition?
questions.solution:
Continuous exposure to sound above 100 dB can cause permanent hearing loss.

Related Pearl: Effects of Noise Exposure

  • Auditory effects
    • Auditory fatigue appears at 90 dB and is greatest at 4000 Hz. Whistling and buzzing in ear occurs with auditory fatigue.
    • Temporary deafness or hearing loss occurs after a single exposure to a noise, usually at a frequency range of 4000 – 6000 Hz. It disappears after 24 hours following noise exposure.
    • Permanent hearing loss can result after continuous or repeated exposure to noises around 100 dB. It occurs commonly as occupational hearing loss.
    • Exposure to noise above 160 dB may rupture the tympanic membrane and cause permanent hearing loss.
  • Non-auditory effects
    • Interference with speech occurs when sound has a frequency of 300 – 500 Hz
    • Annoyance is a psychological response to noise which can greatly affect efficiency and concentration
    • Noise has also been known to cause some physiological changes like increased blood pressure, intracranial pressure, increased sweating, etc.

questions.text: Alkali disease of livestock is caused by an excess of which of the following minerals?
questions.solution:
Excess of selenium causes alkali disease in livestock.

Clinical types of selenium intoxication 

  • Acute selenosis
  • Subacute selenosis (i.e., blind staggers type)
  • Chronic selenosis (i.e., alkali disease type)

Alkali disease occurs when animals consume moderate levels of selenium for a period of weeks to months.

The common clinical signs of chronic selenosis in horses, cattle, and swine are loss of hair (horses and cattle lose long hair from the mane and tails), emaciation, hoof lesions, weight reduction, and lameness.

questions.text: Strychnine toxin acts by blocking the action of glycine at the post-synaptic receptors in the motor neurons of the anterior horn of the spinal cord. Which of the following has a similar mechanism of action but acts presynaptically?
questions.solution:
Tetanus toxin has similar mechanisms of action as strychnine but acts pre-synaptically.

Strychnine prevents the uptake of glycine at inhibitory synapses post-synaptically, while tetanospasmin blocks release of inhibitory neurotransmitters like glycine and gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) pre-synaptically. This leads to increased release of acetylcholine, thereby leading to the development of spastic paralysis.

The image below depicts the mechanism of action of tetanus toxin.

questions.text: A 23 year old patient presents with lesions in the groin as shown in the image below. Which of the following cannot be a cause of these lesions?
questions.solution:
The image shows a well-circumscribed, annular plaque in the groin region which is characteristic of tinea cruris. Tinea cruris is a dermatophytosis. Trichophyton, Microsporum and Epidermophyton are dermatophytes whereas Aspergillus is not.

Dermatophytes include 3 genera: 

  1. Trichophyton species infect skin, hair, and nails and include T. rubrum, T. mentagrophytes, T. tonsurans, T. schoenleinii, and T. violaceum.
  2. Microsporum contains M. gypseum, M. canis, and M. nanum. These infect only hair and skin (not nails).
  3. Floccosum is the only species in the genus Epidermophyton, It infects only skin and nails (not hair).

Aspergillus spp. produce large necrotic lesions like ecthyma gangrenosum, and sometimes small papules and cold abscesses.

questions.text: In a patient with critical limb ischemia, what is the ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) likely to be?
questions.solution:
In a patient with critical limb ischemia, the ABPI is < 0.4.

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.9 to <1.4 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.4 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.

Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

questions.text: A patient presents with breathlessness to the casualty after a motorcycle accident. On examination, the left chest is hyper-resonant on percussion and shows reduced air entry over the same side. His pulse is 110 bpm, RR - 25/min, BP - 80/45mmHg, and JVP was elevated.  What will be your immediate management?

choices.text: Insert a wide bore needle in 5th intercostal space anterior to the mid axillary line
Insert a chest tube in the 5th intercostal space in the anterior axillary line

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of tension pneumothorax. The first line of management in tension pneumothorax is to insert a wide-bore needle in the 5th intercostal space just anterior to the midaxillary line.

Pneumothorax is the abnormal accumulation of air in the pleural space. Tension pneumothorax develops when air enters the pleural space through a point that acts as a one-way valve. More and more air enters with every breath without any way for the air to escape. This is a medical emergency where the patient can quickly deteriorate. 

A patient with pneumothorax presents with acute dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain. A physical examination will reveal:

  • An enlarged hemithorax
  • Decreased chest movements
  • Hyper-resonance on percussion
  • Absent vocal fremitus
  • Diminished breath sounds

In addition to the above findings, a tension pneumothorax would also have the following:

  • Deviation of trachea to the opposite side
  • Distended neck vein
  • Cyanosis
  • Sudden onset hemodynamic compromise:
    • Hypotension
    • Tachycardia
    • Low O2 saturation
    • Loss of consciousness

A diagnosis of tension pneumothorax is usually made based on the clinical findings. If the tension in the pleural cavity is not relieved, the patient can die due to hemodynamic collapse. Hence, treatment should never be delayed waiting for radiological confirmation.

The management of tension pneumothorax is to convert a tension pneumothorax into a simple pneumothorax. This can be done by rapid decompression using a wide-bore cannula on the affected side, followed by the insertion of a chest tube for definitive management.

The safest site for insertion of a drain is in the triangle (Triangle of safety) that lies:

  • Anterior to the mid-axillary line
  • Above the level of the nipple
  • Below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle

Note:

If immediate management is asked, the answer will be to insert a wide-bore needle in the 5th intercostal space in the midaxillary line.

If definitive management is asked, the answer will be to insert an intercostal tube in the triangle of safety.

Recent update:

According to ATLS 10th edition:

  • In adults, needle thoracotomy location changed to 5th ICS at the midaxillary line from 2nd ICS midclavicular line.
  • In the pediatric age group, thoracotomy location remains at the 2nd ICS midclavicular line.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man was admitted with sudden, substernal chest pain radiating to his left arm. On examination, he was diaphoretic and dyspneic with an irregular pulse. Despite resuscitative measures, he died within an hour of admission. Autopsy revealed the following gross appearance of the interventricular myocardium. Which of the following microscopic changes is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image showing dead tissue are suggestive of myocardial infarction. It is characterized by coagulative necrosis.

In coagulative necrosis, despite cell death, the outline and architecture of the cells are preserved for a few days. This is because the cell injury is mainly due to the denaturation of all proteins, including the enzymatic proteins. This prevents the proteolysis of the dead cells. Ultimately, these necrotized cells are removed by phagocytosis and the lysosomal action of the enzymes of the leukocytes.

Examples of coagulative necrosis:

  • Ischemic injury in all organs, except the brain
  • Dry gangrene

questions.text: A patient presents to you with inability to form words but can make noises. He also knows what he wants to say. What area of the brain has been damaged in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Broca's aphasia in which the Broca's area will be affected.

In Broca's aphasia/ Motor aphasia / Non-fluent aphasia, areas 44 and 45 in the prefrontal and premotor facial regions of the cerebral cortex are affected. The affected individuals will have difficulty forming verbal or written words. The comprehension aspect of speech is preserved but the person cannot repeat or name the words and lacks fluency.

Patients in whom the area is severely affected may have very few words to express all of their emotions.

 

Related Pearl: Brodmann areas

Area of the Brain(Brodmann) Location
3, 1 and 2 - Primary sensory area

Postcentral gyrus

Extends to the posterior part of the paracentral lobule medially
4 - Primary motor area

Precentral gyrus

Extends to the anterior part of the paracentral lobule medially
6- Premotor area

Anterior to Area 4

In the posterior parts of superior, middle and inferior frontal gyri
5 and 7 - Sensory association area Superior parietal lobule
8 - Frontal eye field Posterior part of middle frontal gyrus, anterior to the facial area of the precentral gyrus
44 and 45 - Broca’s(Motor speech) area Inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere

41 and 42 - 

Primary auditory area

 Superior surface of the superior temporal gyrus(Heschl’s gyrus)
22* - Wernicke’s(Sensory speech) area Superior temporal gyrus
17 - Primary visual(striate) area Walls and floor of the posterior part of calcarine sulcus (postcalcarine sulcus) in the occipital lobe

18 and 19- 

Visual association area

 Remaining part of the medial and superolateral surfaces of the occipital lobe
28 - Primary olfactory area Anterior part of the parahippocampal gyrus and uncus
43 - Gustatory(taste) area Inferior part of the parietal lobe, posterior to the general sensory area of the mouth

*There is uncertainty about the extent of the Wernicke's area. Some authorities consider areas 39 and 40 as part of Wernicke's area in addition to area 22.

Related Pearl: Aphasias and Related Conditions

questions.text: Screening of a CSF sample is done by using:

choices.text: Antigen testing with a rapid test

questions.solution:
Gram staining is the preferred method of screening a CSF sample. Molecular methods can also be used when available as they have a higher sensitivity and specificity.  

Bacterial antigen testing of CSF using rapid tests are no longer recommended as a screening tool as they are no more sensitive than gram staining. However, they may be used as an adjunct to gram staining.  

Cultures are not used as a screening modality.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presented with recurrent episodes of flank pain and fever with chills.  CECT abdomen showed dilated and enlarged left renal pelvis with the multiloculated calyces and resection of the kidney was done. The gross specimen showed large yellowish-orange nodules. Histological examination revealed foamy macrophages.  Which of the following is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and histological findings are suggestive of xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis. It is associated with Proteus infection and obstructive uropathy. 

Xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis is a relatively rare form of chronic pyelonephritis characterized by the accumulation of foamy macrophages intermingled with plasma cells, lymphocytes, polymorphonuclear leukocytes, and occasional giant cells.

The lesions sometimes produce large, yellowish-orange nodules that may be grossly confused with renal cell carcinoma. CECT abdomen shows dilated and enlarged renal pelvis and calyces showing a multiloculated appearance referred to as the bear paw sign.

questions.text: The histopathological slide given below is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
The given slide shows a row of tombstones appearance, which is classically seen in pemphigus vulgaris. 

In this condition, there is a suprabasal splitting of the epidermis leading to blister formation. The basal layer remains adherent to the basement membrane and gives the resemblance to a row of tombstones as shown in the histology image below.

Pemphigus vulgaris is a chronic immunobullous disorder characterized by the presence of antibodies against desmosomal proteins, desmogleins 1 and 3 expressed in the skin and mucosa.

Clinically, the patients present with ill-defined, irregular, slow-to-heal oral lesions and erosions. Flaccid blisters filled with clear fluid may arise on normal skin or an erythematous base. The rupture of such blisters produces painful erosions and heals without scarring.

Nikolsky's sign is positive which is elicited by applying firm tangential sliding pressure with a finger on lesional or perilesional skin. This leads to the separation of the normal‐looking epidermis from the dermis, producing erosion.

Direct immunofluorescence is considered the most accurate confirmatory test of this condition. It shows intercellular IgG and C3 deposition on the surface of keratinocytes throughout the epidermis in normal, perilesional skin, in a characteristic fishnet/chickenwire appearance as seen below.

questions.text: A diagnostic laparoscopy was performed on a 27-year-old woman with severe dysmenorrhoea and dyspareunia.  The following finding was seen on the pelvic peritoneum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the image showing characteristic powder burn spots seen over the pelvic peritoneum on laparoscopy point toward a diagnosis of pelvic endometriosis.

On laparoscopy, the typical endometriotic lesions appear like small black, dark brown or bluish dots. These are called powder burns or gunshot appearance of the serosal surfaces of the peritoneum. They are nodules or small cysts containing old haemorrhages surrounded by a variable degree of fibrosis.

Subtle appearances of endometriosis seen on laparoscopy are:

  • Red flame-shaped areas
  • Red polypoid areas
  • Yellow-brown patches
  • White peritoneal plaques or scarring
  • Peritoneal defects - known as Allen Masters Syndrome
  • Subovarian adhesions.

The lesions mentioned above are thought to be more active than the powder burn areas.

Endometriotic lesions in the peritoneal cavity contain yellowish-brown fluid. This fluid contains prostaglandins that are responsible for the pain associated with this condition. Endometriosis of the ovary leads to formation of the chocolate cyst which is a true cyst with columnar epithelium lining.

The image below shows the laparoscopic appearance of endometriotic lesions in the pouch of Douglas and on the right, the sacrouterine ligament. Dyspareunia occurs when the pouch of Douglas and rectovaginal septum are involved.

questions.text: A screening test was carried out among 114 people out of which 15 have a disease. The test showed 22 people tested positive for the disease among which 14 actually had the disease. What is the sensitivity of the test?
questions.solution:
The sensitivity of the above screening test is 93%.

The given data is represented below

 

Disease +

Disease -

Total

Test +

14(TP)

8(FP)

22

Test -

1(FN)

91(TN)

92

Total

15(TP+FN)

99(FP+TN)

114

TP- true positive, FP- false positive, FN- false negative, TN- true negative

Sensitivity is given as TP/(TP + FN) x 100 = 14/15 = 93%.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the pathogenesis of pre-eclampsia?

choices.text: Vascular sensitivity to angiotensin 2 is increased
There is an increase in sFlt -1 levels
A decrease in the level of soluble endoglin is seen

questions.solution:
In pre-eclampsia, there is an increase in the level of soluble endoglin.

Excessive amounts of antiangiogenic factors, increased sensitivity to angiotensin, and lowered angiotensinase levels worsen hypoxia at the uteroplacental interface.

Trophoblast of women who develop preeclampsia overproduces at least two antiangiogenic peptides that enter the maternal circulation. They increase months before clinical preeclampsia develops.

  • Soluble endoglin (sEng) is derived from the placenta and blocks endothelial nitric oxide-dependent vasodilatation. It also inhibits various TGFβ isoforms from binding to endothelial receptors.
  • Soluble Fms-like tyrosine kinase 1 (sFlt-1) is a variant of the Flt-1 receptor for placental growth factor (PlGF) and for VEGF. Increased maternal sFlt-1 levels inactivate and decrease circulating free PlGF and VEGF concentrations, leading to endothelial dysfunction.

questions.text: Which of the following represents a holocrine gland?
questions.solution:
The histopathological image marked ‘B’ represents the sebaceous gland, which is a type of holocrine gland.

Holocrine secretions are produced in the cytoplasm of the cell and released by the rupture of the plasma membrane, which destroys the cell and results in the secretion of the product into the lumen.

Examples of holocrine glands are

  • Sebaceous glands of the skin and
  • Meibomian glands of the eyelid

Image A: Sweat glands - Eccrine/merocrine glands; glands remain intact

Image C: Mammary gland - Apocrine gland; apical part sheds to secrete

Image D: Ceruminous gland - Apocrine glands

questions.text: All are true about the condition that is diagnosed by the given ECG except:

choices.text: Can be seen in asymptomatic individuals
Caused by an abnormal accessory pathway

questions.solution:
The given ECG is suggestive of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (WPW). Its prevalence decreases with age.

The classic ECG features in WPW are as follows:

  • A shortened PR interval (typically <120 ms)
  • A slurring and the slow rise of the initial upstroke of the QRS complex (delta wave)
  • A widened QRS complex (total duration >0.12 seconds)
  • ST-segment–T wave (repolarization) changes, generally directed opposite the major delta wave and QRS complex, reflecting altered depolarization

Related Pearl: Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome

Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome (WPW) is characterized by an abnormal accessory pathway in the heart leading to arrhythmias.

Pathology- Born with an accessory pathway, the bundle of Kent which connects the atria and ventricle. The electrical impulses from the SA node reach the ventricles earlier via the accessory pathway as there is no AV nodal delay in this pathway. This leads to the preexcitation of the ventricle and initiation of ventricular contraction. This ventricular contraction is prolonged when the impulse via the AV nodal pathway reaches the ventricles.

Most common location of the accessory pathway- between the left atrium and free wall of the left ventricle

ECG changes:

Shortened PR interval- because of the early initiation of ventricular depolarization

Prolonged QRS duration- because of the AV nodal impulse reaching the ventricles after the aberrant impulse.

Delta waves- slurred upstroke of QRS complex

The given ECG shows delta waves marked with red arrows:

Treatment:

  • Catheter ablation is the treatment of choice.
  • Anti-arrhythmic drugs like procainamide, amiodarone, quinidine, propafenone, dofetilide are used in slowing conduction in the accessory pathway (prolong refractory period).
  • IV procainamide is the drug of choice in a hemodynamically stable WPW presenting with atrial fibrillation.
  • DC cardioversion is done in hemodynamically unstable patients.

questions.text: Which among the following reduces the risk of developing ovarian cancers?
questions.solution:
Bilateral tubectomy and hysterectomy reduce the risk of ovarian cancer.

Some ovarian malignancies originate in the fallopian tubes as dysplastic lesions which later spread to the ovary (dropping down theory). Thus, bilateral tubectomy reduces the risk of ovarian malignancy.

Risk factors for ovarian cancer:

  • Advancing age
  • Early menarche and late menopause
  • Talc exposure to the perineum
  • Family history of breast / ovarian cancer
  • Ovulation induction therapy by clomiphene citrate

Protective factors against ovarian cancer:

  • Use of oral contraceptive pills
  • Multiparity
  • Breastfeeding
  • Anovulation.

questions.text: Choose the correct order of suctioning during neonatal resuscitation.
questions.solution:
During neonatal resuscitation, the mouth is suctioned first and then the nares, in order to decrease the risk of aspiration. A 12 or 14 French suction catheter is used, with the suction pressure kept between 80-100mmHg.

Routine suctioning of the trachea during neonatal resuscitation is not recommended. The suctioning of the esophagus and stomach is avoided if not indicated specifically, as it can produce a vagal response due to stimulation in the posterior pharynx, resulting in apnea and/or bradycardia.

The steps in neonatal resuscitation follow the ABCs, Airway, Breathing, and Circulation.

The neonatal resuscitation algorithm is given below:

Chest compression should be initiated over the lower third of the sternum at a rate of 90/minutes. The ratio of chest compression to ventilation is 3: 1 (90 compressions: 30 breaths). The thumb technique (preferred) and 2 finger technique are the two different techniques used for performing chest compression. Umbilical vein cannulation is the preferred method for the administration of medications.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought to the OPD with complaints of passing loose bulky stools that were associated with abdominal pain for the past 20 days. The stool examination showed the following organism. Which of the following is false about this disease?

choices.text: Caused by ingestion of mature cyst
ELISA  is more sensitive and specific than microscopy
Albendazole is the drug of choice

questions.solution:
The given clinical history and image showing the pear or tennis racket-shaped trophozoite form is suggestive of giardiasis. The drugs of choice are metronidazole and tinidazole.

Infection occurs by the ingestion of mature cysts in contaminated water and food.

Giardiasis usually occurs in immunosuppressive conditions, agammaglobulinemia, or in malnourished individuals.

Clinical features:

  • Diarrhea 
  • Fat malabsorption
  • Dull epigastric pain
  • Belching and flatulence
  • Iron deficiency and growth stunting.
  • Stool will have excess mucus and fat but no blood.

Detection of antigen by ELISA is more sensitive and specific than microscopy. Entero test is also used in the diagnosis.

Metronidazole/tinidazole/nitazoxanide are the first-line agents in the treatment.

Giardia is also known as the grand old man of the intestine.
